According to the narrative, the Israelites were instructed to mark the doorposts of their homes with the blood of a slaughtered spring lamb so that the spirit of the Lord knew to pass over these homes, hence the name of the holiday. Traditionally observed for eight days by many Jewish communities, it involves rituals such as the Seder meal, which includes reading from the Haggadah, eating matzah, and other symbolic foods. What is the name of this holiday that begins on the 15th of the Hebrew month of Nissan?

Spanning several countries in southern Africa, this vast semi-arid sandy savanna is known for its red sand, sparse vegetation, and diverse wildlife, including meerkats and the famous black-maned lions. Despite its dry conditions, it supports more animal and plant life than a true desert. The region is also home to the indigenous San people, who have adapted traditional techniques to survive its harsh environment. What is the name of this desert that stretches across Botswana, parts of Namibia, and South Africa?

This Belgian former professional cyclist, often hailed as the most accomplished rider in the history of the sport, won the Tour de France five times during his career in the late 1960s and early 1970s. His dominance extended beyond France into the Giro d'Italia, which he also won five times, and he achieved a record 34 stage wins in the Tour de France. Known for his nickname "The Cannibal" due to his relentless competitive drive, what is the name of this legendary cyclist?

Initiated by the Latin Church in the medieval period, these campaigns aimed to reclaim Jerusalem and other holy lands from Muslim control, beginning in the late 11th century and lasting until the late 13th century. Over time, the objectives expanded to encompass various political, economic, and territorial motives. Significantly shaping Christian and Muslim relations, these events had a profound impact on the geography and politics of the Middle East. What is the general term for these historical campaigns?

Triggered by various events such as undersea earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, underwater landslides, or meteorite impacts, these high-energy sea waves can cause catastrophic damage when they reach coastal areas. Notably, the 2004 Indian Ocean event highlighted the critical need for early warning systems to prevent disasters. What is the term used to describe these powerful series of ocean waves?

This project was initiated in response to fears that Nazi Germany would develop nuclear weapons first. It began in 1942 and involved some of the greatest scientific minds of the time, including Robert Oppenheimer and Enrico Fermi. It led to the development and testing of the first nuclear weapons in Los Alamos, New Mexico. The culmination of this project was the dropping of atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945, significantly impacting the conclusion of World War II. What is the name of this pivotal scientific and military project?

This poet and Nobel laureate, who adopted a pen name to avoid conflict with his father, became a senator for the Chilean Communist Party. Renowned for his passionate love poems and odes to ordinary objects, his most famous collection, "Twenty Love Poems and a Song of Despair," was published in his youth. He later served as a diplomat in various countries, writing the poem "I Explain a Few Things" during the Spanish Civil War.

At the age of 14, this Romanian gymnast made history at the 1976 Montreal Olympics by becoming the first gymnast to score a perfect 10.0 in an Olympic event, a feat she achieved not once, but seven times throughout the competition. Her flawless routines on the uneven bars and balance beam earned her three gold medals, including the prestigious all-around title. Name this gymnast who added two more gold medals in the 1980 Olympics.

This U.S. Senator and his wife, Nadine, are currently facing trial for bribery charges over alleged gifts from Egyptian and Qatari nationals in exchange for favorable treatment. In 2015 this same Senator was charged in a separate corruption case which eventually ended when the charges were dropped in 2018. This Democrat is the senior Senator from New Jersey, serving since 2006. Name this politician who chaired the Committee on Foreign relations from 2013-2015 and 2021-2023.

This transcontinental city straddles the Bosphorus Strait, a natural waterway that serves as a boundary between two continents. Its strategic location has made it a coveted prize throughout history, leading to its role as the capital of both the Byzantine and Ottoman Empires. Historically known as Byzantium and Constantinople, a blend of Eastern and Western influences is evident in its architecture, cuisine, and culture. Which city, the largest in Turkey, is the only metropolis in the world situated on two continents?

This American president had a centrist political philosophy which became known as the "Third Way". He was the first president born in the Baby Boomer generation and participated in the Camp David Summit to advance the Israeli–Palestinian peace process. He was twice elected governor of Arkansas and defeated George H.W. Bush and Bob Dole as he was elected President twice. Name this 42nd President who married Hillary Rodham.

This science fiction franchise, despite initial cancellation after three seasons, gained a cult following through syndicated reruns and spawned a media empire. It premiered in 1966 with a multiracial crew led by Captain James T. Kirk aboard the USS Enterprise. Its creator, Gene Roddenberry, envisioned a future where humanity united to explore the galaxy. The show's original mission was "to explore strange new worlds, to seek out new life and new civilizations, to boldly go where no man has gone before."

This British politician and writer served as First Lord of the Admiralty during World War I but was demoted after the disastrous Gallipoli Campaign. He is most known for his wartime leadership during World War II, where he delivered powerful speeches, including "We shall fight on the beaches." He earned a Nobel Prize in Literature in 1953 for books he wrote about his WWII experiences. Name this British statesman who served two terms as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom and who coined the phrase "Iron Curtain" in a famous speech.

This international scientific research project was declared essentially complete in 2003, with 92% of human DNA sequenced. A working draft was announced in 2000, a significant milestone in the project's timeline. Led by an international consortium of scientists, it involved mapping and deciphering the 3 billion base pairs that make up human DNA. This ambitious endeavor sought to map and understand all the genes of human beings. What was the name of this project, which has since revolutionized fields from medicine to forensics?

This Prussian statesman, born into the Junker nobility, orchestrated the unification of Germany in 1871 through a series of strategic wars, including victories over Austria and France. This man served as the first Chancellor of the German Empire from 1871 to 1890, and became known as the "Iron Chancellor". Who is this leader known for his strong leadership and Realpolitik approach to politics?

Constructed on an artificial island at the entrance of Charleston Harbor in South Carolina, this masonry fort was named for a Revolutionary War hero. It was designed to protect the harbor from naval attacks and became a focal point of tension between the Union and the Confederacy in the lead-up to the Civil War. Following South Carolina's secession from the Union in December 1860, the fort's commander, Major Robert Anderson, refused to surrender it to Confederate authorities, leading to a bombardment that marked the official beginning of the Civil War in April 1861.

This British actress and fashion icon, known for her roles in classic films during Hollywood's Golden Age, epitomized elegance and charm with her performances in "Breakfast at Tiffany's," "Roman Holiday," for which she won an Academy Award, and "My Fair Lady." Beyond her film career, she was also celebrated for her humanitarian work with UNICEF. Her style and grace left a lasting impression on the fashion and film industries. What is the name of this beloved actress and philanthropist, renowned for both her distinctive cinematic roles and her dedication to charity?

This single-stranded molecule, essential for protein synthesis, comes in three main types: messenger, transfer, and ribosomal. It carries genetic code from DNA, delivers amino acids to the ribosome, and forms a key component of ribosomes. Which molecule, found in all living cells and some viruses, serves as a vital link between genetic information and protein production, making it indispensable for life?

This athlete was the first player in NCAA history to lead the nation in both points and assists in a single season. She was named the consensus National Player of the Year in 2023, winning the Naismith Trophy, the Wade Trophy, and the Wooden Award. She led her team to the NCAA championship game in 2023, where they lost to LSU. Name this Iowa Hawkeyes star who was selected as the first overall pick in the 2024 WNBA draft by the Indiana Fever.

This playwright, who married Marilyn Monroe in 1956, was once blacklisted by the House Un-American Activities Committee for refusing to name suspected communists. He is celebrated for his powerful portrayals of American life and social injustice, particularly in plays exploring themes of guilt, responsibility, and the American Dream. Two of his most notable works include "The Crucible," a drama about the Salem witch trials that serves as an allegory for McCarthyism, and "Death of a Salesman," a tragedy about a struggling salesman who grapples with disillusionment and failure.

This historic city, located in the Île-de-France region, lies within a basin on the Seine River, approximately 233 miles from its mouth on the English Channel. Its urban landscape is characterized by wide boulevards and a harmonious blend of Haussmannian architecture and iconic landmarks like the Eiffel Tower and Arc de Triomphe. The city is divided into 20 arrondissements, spiraling outward from the historic center on the Île de la Cité. Which city, renowned for its art, fashion, and cuisine, serves as the capital of France and a global center of culture?

This Spanish football club is one of the most successful and popular sports teams globally. Founded in 1902, it has won numerous domestic league titles and holds the record for the most UEFA Champions League victories. Known for their iconic white kits, the club has a storied history featuring legendary players such as Alfredo Di Stefano, Cristiano Ronaldo, and Zinedine Zidane. Their intense rivalry with FC Barcelona, known as "El Clasico," is one of the most famous in sports. What is the name of this football club, renowned for its rich history and success in both national and international competitions?

The series finale of this coming-of-age sitcom aired on May 16, 2024 on CBS after seven seasons. This show, filmed in front of a live studio audience, follows the life of a child prodigy in East Texas. It gained a surprising new fan base when it was released on Netflix in Fall 2021. Name this CBS sitcom that is narrated by Jim Parsons and follows the early life of Parsons's character previously featured in the hit show "The Big Bang Theory."

This revolutionary, born Ioseb Besarionis dze Jughashvili, adopted a pseudonym meaning "man of steel." He orchestrated the Great Purge, a period of political repression and executions. His Five-Year Plans aimed to rapidly industrialize the Soviet Union. As General Secretary of the Communist Party, he led the Soviet Union during World War II and the beginning of the Cold War. Name this Soviet leader.

An engineering student at Oregon State University, this athlete struggled to master the straddle and western roll high jump techniques. After experimenting with unconventional methods, he developed a revolutionary back-first technique that he unveiled at the 1968 Mexico City Olympics. Despite initial skepticism, this technique propelled him to a gold medal and quickly became the dominant style in high jump, which now bears his name followed by an alliterative "Flop."

This cellular structure, a network of interconnected membranous sacs and tubules, plays a crucial role in protein and lipid synthesis. It is divided into two distinct regions: rough, studded with ribosomes and involved in protein production and folding, and smooth, lacking ribosomes and responsible for lipid metabolism and detoxification. Found in all eukaryotic cells, its expansive surface area facilitates its diverse functions. What is the name of this organelle, often referred to as the "highway" of the cell due to its role in transporting molecules?

Emerging in neutral Switzerland during World War I as a reaction against the war's violence and nationalism, this artistic and literary movement embraced chaos, irrationality, and nonsense. It challenged traditional notions of art and aesthetics, employing techniques like collage, photomontage, and readymades. The name of this movement, possibly chosen at random from a dictionary, is often associated with anti-establishment sentiments. What is the name of this movement whose prominent figures included Tristan Tzara, Marcel Duchamp, and Hugo Ball?

A staunch advocate for democracy, this U.S. president was the first to hold a Ph.D. and taught political science at Princeton University before entering politics. He led the nation through World War I, coining the phrase "The world must be made safe for democracy." However, his dream of establishing the League of Nations faced opposition in Congress, and his health suffered a severe blow when he experienced a debilitating stroke in 1919. Who was this 28th President of the United States who envisioned a new world order after the Great War?

This island city-state, located at the southern tip of the Malay Peninsula, consists of one main island and 62 smaller islets. It is separated from Malaysia by the Johor Strait and from Indonesia by a strait which shares its name. Despite its small size of approximately 734 square kilometers, it is a global financial hub and a major shipping center, boasting the world's busiest transshipment port. Its diverse population comprises predominantly Chinese, Malay, and Indian ethnic groups. Which city-state, known for its cleanliness, efficiency, and strict laws, is a popular destination for both business and leisure travelers?

This popular sitcom, filmed in black and white for its first five seasons, was a spin-off of "The Danny Thomas Show." Set in the fictional town of Mayberry, North Carolina, it followed the life of a widowed sheriff, his son, and his bumbling deputy. The show's gentle humor, heartwarming storylines, and memorable characters like Aunt Bee, Gomer Pyle, and Floyd the Barber made it a beloved classic, ranking among the most-watched shows from 1960-1968. Name this iconic comedy series starring Andy Griffith, Ron Howard, and Don Knotts.

Born James Cleveland in Oakville, Alabama, this athlete moved to Cleveland, Ohio at age nine. He won four gold medals at the 1936 Berlin Olympics in the 100 meters, 200 meters, long jump, and 4x100 meter relay. His victories challenged Adolf Hitler's propaganda about Aryan racial superiority, as he set Olympic records in the long jump and 200 meters and equaled the world record in the 100 meters. Name this American Olympic icon.

In the 1960s, Canadian scientists Ernest A. McCulloch and James E. Till made a groundbreaking discovery of these cells in mouse bone marrow. Classified into two main types, embryonic and adult, they offer vast potential in regenerative medicine, but also raise ethical concerns, especially with embryonic sources. Their unique ability to differentiate into specialized cells has led to promising research in treating diseases like Parkinson's and diabetes. What are these cells, hailed as a potential breakthrough in medicine yet also the subject of ongoing ethical discussions?

This European nation established a colony in 1908 which encompassed a vast territory in Central Africa rich in natural resources such as rubber, ivory, and minerals. It gained notoriety for the harsh treatment of the indigenous population under the rule of King Leopold II, leading to international condemnation and a humanitarian crisis. The colonial region ultimately achieved independence in from this nation in 1960, adopting the name Republic of the Congo before later changing it. Name the European nation which held colonial control over the Congo for over five decades.

This American president graduated from Eureka College in Illinois and began his career as a sportcaster in Iowa in 1932. He later served as the President of the Screen Actor's Guild then governor of California. John Hinckley attempted to assassinate this man in during his first term, thinking it would impress the actress Jodie Foster. Name this 40th US President who defeated Jimmy Carter and Walter Mondale.

Debuting in 1975, this iconic American television show is known for its live sketch comedy and variety performances. Created by Lorne Michaels, it has launched the careers of many comedians and actors, becoming a staple of weekend television. The show is renowned for its topical humor, parodies of political figures, and musical performances, making it a significant part of American pop culture. It has also won numerous Emmy Awards over the decades. What is the name of this long-running program that features a different celebrity host and musical guest each week?

This Harlem Renaissance poet, who once worked as a busboy, is celebrated for his vibrant depictions of African American life and culture, often incorporating elements of jazz and blues into his writing. Two of his most famous poems include "I, Too," a defiant declaration of racial equality, and "Harlem," a poignant exploration of deferred dreams. He is considered a pioneer of jazz poetry, and his works continue to inspire and resonate with readers today.

This vibrant city, nestled between lush mountains and the Atlantic Ocean, is famous for its dramatic landscape, featuring iconic landmarks such as Sugarloaf Mountain and the Christ the Redeemer statue. Its world-renowned Carnival celebrations, filled with music, dance, and elaborate costumes, attract millions of visitors each year. The city's Guanabara Bay, one of the world's largest natural harbors, is dotted with picturesque islands and surrounded by stunning beaches like Copacabana and Ipanema. Which city, the second most populous in Brazil, served as the nation's capital from 1763 to 1960?

This television show concluded its 25th season on May 16, 2024, extending it's record as the longest-running primetime action series. It airs on NBC and was created by Dick Wolf as a spin off of a classic procedural crime drama. This series focused on two detectives as they investigate and prosecute sexually based crimes in New York City. Name this TV show which stars Mariska Hargitay and Christopher Meloni which was the first spin off from Law and Order.
answers: law and order: special victims unit

question: This organelle, named after its Italian discoverer in 1897, is often referred to as the cell's "post office" due to its role in modifying, sorting, and packaging proteins and lipids. It consists of a series of flattened, stacked pouches called cisternae, and plays a crucial role in the secretory pathway. What is the name of this organelle, essential for cellular transport and processing?

Orphaned as a teenager and captured by the British during the Revolutionary War, this future president survived an assassination attempt in 1835 when his would-be killer's pistols misfired. Nicknamed "Old Hickory" for his toughness, he rose from humble beginnings to become a lawyer, planter, and military leader. This seventh U.S. president is remembered for his controversial policies towards Native Americans, including the Indian Removal Act and the Trail of Tears. Who is this prominent figure in American history?

This historic city, built on seven hills, straddles the Tiber River in the Lazio region of central Italy. Its strategic location on the river, approximately 15 miles inland from the Tyrrhenian Sea, contributed to its rise as a powerful empire. The city's iconic landmarks, including the Colosseum, the Pantheon, and the Forum, are testaments to its rich history and cultural significance. Which city, often called the "Eternal City," serves as the capital of Italy and the spiritual center of the Catholic Church, with Vatican City located entirely within its boundaries?

This iconic American actress, model, and singer, born Norma Jeane Mortenson in 1926, became one of the most popular sex symbols of the 1950s and early 1960s. Renowned for her comedic "blonde bombshell" roles, she starred in several successful films, including "Some Like It Hot" and "The Seven Year Itch," the latter featuring the famous scene of her standing over a subway grate as her white dress is blown upwards. Her life, marked by glamour and personal struggles, ended tragically in 1962. What is the name of this legendary film star known for her beauty and tragic life story?

This region, notorious for its rugged terrain and dense rainforests, poses a significant challenge to travelers and remains a missing link in the Pan-American Highway. It's a biodiversity hotspot, home to a wide array of flora and fauna, including jaguars, harpy eagles, and poisonous dart frogs. Indigenous groups like the Embera and Wounaan have inhabited the area for centuries. In recent years, it has become an increasingly perilous route for migrants fleeing economic and political instability, seeking passage between South and Central America. What is the name of this 66-mile stretch of undeveloped wilderness between Panama and Colombia?

This Austrian-born corporal and failed artist served in the Bavarian Army during World War I. He rose to power as the charismatic leader of the National Socialist German Workers' Party, becoming Chancellor of Germany in 1933. His hateful ideology, outlined in his book Mein Kampf, led to the persecution and genocide of Jews and other minorities in the Holocaust. His aggressive expansionist policies, including the annexation of Austria and invasion of Poland, plunged the world into the devastating conflict of World War II. Who is this infamous dictator who committed suicide in a Berlin bunker in 1945?

Nicknamed "Big Red," this chestnut racehorse with three white stockings won the Triple Crown in 1973, setting records in all three races that still stand today. His Belmont Stakes victory, a 31-length triumph, is considered one of the greatest performances in horse racing history. Upon his death, his heart was found to be more than twice the size of an average horse's heart, a possible explanation for his exceptional speed and endurance. Name this legendary racehorse.

This openly gay American poet, known for his raw and confessional style, wrote a controversial poem which led to a landmark trial for freedom of speech in 1957. A leading figure of the Beat Generation, he was expelled from Columbia University for writing obscene graffiti and befriended other Beat icons like Jack Kerouac and William S. Burroughs. His works often explored themes of sexuality, spirituality, and the American experience, with notable poems including "Howl", "Kaddish", and "America."

Born in Texas and raised in Kansas, this five-star general served as Supreme Commander of the Allied Forces in Europe during World War II, overseeing the D-Day invasion of Normandy. A gifted strategist and charismatic leader, he later became president of Columbia University before being elected President of the United States. Known for his "Atoms for Peace" speech and his farewell address warning of the "military-industrial complex," he championed infrastructure development with the Interstate Highway System during his two terms in office. Who is this military hero and 34th President of the United States?

This politician is being investigated by the FBI for possible campaign violations related to illegal fundraising from Turkish nationals. Before he was a politician, this man served as a New York police office for more than 20 years. He went on to become the first Black President of Brooklyn Borough in New York in 2013. In 2021, this man was elected Mayor of New York over Curtis Silwa.

This exiled revolutionary adopted a pseudonym derived from the Lena River. This man published the "April Theses" which led to the October Revolution, in which his Bolsheviks overthrew the Russian regime. An offshoot ideology of Marxism bares his name. Name this man who was the first leader of the Soviet Union from 1922-1924.

This sprawling metropolis, the third most populous in Africa, traces its roots back to a Roman fortress established in the 1st century AD. Its name, derived from the Arabic word "Al-Qahirah" meaning "the victorious," reflects its historical significance as a center of power and culture. Located near the apex of the Nile Delta, it boasts iconic landmarks such as the Citadel of Salah al-Din and the Mosque of Muhammad Ali. Which city, a modern-day megacity with a population exceeding 20 million, is home to the renowned Museum of Egyptian Antiquities, housing a vast collection of ancient artifacts, including the treasures of Tutankhamun?

Overcoming polio as a child, this athlete became the first American woman to win three gold medals in track and field at a single Olympic Games. Competing at the 1960 Rome Olympics, she dominated the 100-meter and 200-meter sprints, as well as the 4x100-meter relay, solidifying her place as one of the greatest female athletes of all time. Name this athlete who retired from competition at the peak of her athletic career in 1962 and went on to graduate from Tennessee State University and become an educator and coach.

This German astronomer, mathematician, and author was born in Weil der Stadt in 1571. Despite suffering from smallpox as a child, he worked as an assistant to Tycho Brahe and later succeeded him as the imperial mathematician. He has been described as the "father of science fiction" for his novel Somnium. He is most known for his three laws of planetary motion, which revolutionized our understanding of the solar system and paved the way for Isaac Newton's law of universal gravitation. Who was this key figure in the scientific revolution?

This popular Christmas character, created by Robert L. May for a Montgomery Ward promotional booklet, was initially rejected by the company's executives for his unusual physical trait. Voiced by Billie Mae Richards in the 1964 stop-motion animated television special, this character is ostracized for his unusual nose but eventually becomes a hero when his unique attribute proves essential for guiding Santa's sleigh through a blizzard. The character's story has been adapted into numerous songs, movies, and television shows, and has become a beloved symbol of acceptance and embracing differences.

Originally written in French during World War II, this allegorical novella tells the story of a young prince who travels from his asteroid to Earth, encountering various characters like a vain rose, a conceited king, and a drunkard. The book is beloved for its simple yet profound message about the importance of childlike wonder and imagination, and it has been translated into over 500 languages, making it the second most translated book of all time after The Bible. What is the name of this book which has sold over 140 million copies?

This party was founded by several ex-Whigs. Past leaders of this party include Newt Gingrich, the creator of the Contract with America, and Teddy Roosevelt. One member of this party made a campaign pledge of "no new taxes," and Libertarians traditionally run under this major party's banner. It is currently chaired by Michael Whatley. Name this major party also called the "Grand Old Party."

This American city, built on three islands - Manhattan, Staten Island, and part of Long Island - is home to five boroughs, each with its own distinct character. The city is also home to Central Park, an 843-acre oasis in the heart of Manhattan, and the Statue of Liberty, a symbol of freedom and democracy. What is the name of this bustling metropolis, known for its skyscrapers, Broadway theaters, and diverse population?

This NFL team, established in 1919, is the only community-owned franchise in the league. It boasts a passionate fanbase known as "Cheeseheads," who often wear foam cheese-shaped hats to games. The team's colors are green and gold, and their logo features a white oval with a green "G" inside. They have won four Super Bowl championships, including the first two Super Bowls. What is the name of this team, whose home stadium is Lambeau Field in Wisconsin?

This restaurateur and television personality is known for his distinctive blonde spiky hair and goatee. He studied abroad as an exchange student in Chantilly, France, which expanded his culinary horizons. He gained widespread recognition by winning the second season of The Next Food Network Star in 2006. Who is this celebrity chef, known for his catchphrase "Flavortown" and hosting shows like "Diners, Drive-Ins and Dives"?

This man described a trip around America with his poodle in Travels with Charley. In a novella by this man, George shoots Lennie to prevent him from being lynched. This man also wrote about the Joad family's attempt to escape the Depression by moving to California from Oklahoma. Identify this American author of Of Mice and Men and The Grapes of Wrath.

Despite being heavily guarded, this structure was successfully breached over 5,000 times by individuals using creative methods like hot air balloons, tunnels, and even tightropes. Its construction led to the displacement of over 100,000 people, and its existence became a focal point for Cold War tensions and a symbol of oppression. The first victim of this barrier was Ida Siekmann, who died while attempting to jump from her apartment window in East Berlin. What is the name of this infamous structure, which divided a city and a nation for 28 years?

Robert Fico, the Prime Minister for this nation was shot in an assassination attempt on May 15, 2024. The Central European country, known for its medieval castles and picturesque mountain ranges, is home to the High Tatras, the smallest high mountain range in the world. Its capital, Bratislava, is the only capital city that borders two other countries, Austria and Hungary. What is the name of this country, whose national dish is bryndzové halušky, potato dumplings with sheep cheese and bacon?

This constellation is often interpreted as fighting Taurus with his dogs Canis Minor and Canis Major. Stars within this constellation include the "amazon star" Bellatrix, the red giant Betelgeuse, and Rigel. It is most easily recognizable by the three stars making up the belt of the figure in this constellation. Name this constellation also known as "the Hunter."

On May 19, 2024, this nation's President died in a helicopter crash while flying back from neighboring Azerbaijan. Although they have a president, the country is led by Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei, the longest serving head of state in the Middle East. The United States and its allies agreed to the Joint Comprehensive Plan on Action to end economic sanctions on this nation in exchange for a restriction on producing enriched uranium for nuclear weapons. The United States pulled out of this deal during the Trump Administration. Name this nation formerly known as Persia.

Formed in London in 1962, this band is known for their iconic tongue and lips logo, their blues-inspired sound, and their rebellious image. Their 1969 album "Let It Bleed" included hits like "Gimme Shelter" and "You Can't Always Get What You Want." Who is this legendary band, fronted by Mick Jagger and Keith Richards?

This five-week battle in 1945 was immortalized by Joe Rosenthal's Pulitzer Prize-winning photograph of six US Marines raising the American flag atop Mount Suribachi. The iconic black sand beaches of this island were the site of the initial landings, and the battle saw some of the fiercest fighting of the Pacific War. What is the name of this battle, which ultimately resulted in an American victory, but with heavy casualties on both sides?

This NFL team, established in 1959 as the Titans, is the only team in NFL history to win its lone Super Bowl appearance, defeating the heavily favored Baltimore Colts in Super Bowl III. Their victory was led by quarterback Joe Namath, who famously guaranteed a win before the game. The team's colors are green and white. What is the name of this team, whose home stadium is MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, New Jersey?

This man wrote about an animal who steals from the farmers Boggis, Bunce and Bean in The Fantastic Mister Fox. He also wrote about a girl with psychic powers who reads every book in the library and then loses her powers in Miss Honey's class in his book Matilda. A better known book by this man sees its title fruit get stuck on top of the Empire State Building. Name this author of James and the Giant Peach.

The law of these objects states that the torque on one side is equal to the torque on the other side. These objects can be classified as first class, second class, or third class depending on the location of the fulcrum. Name these simple machines, familiar examples of which include a wheelbarrow and see-saw.

Landmarks on this island include the El Yunque rainforest and Fort San Felipe del Moro. Humacao, Caguas, Bayamon, and Ponce are some of its municipalities. The largest municipality shares the name given to the island by Columbus, San Juan. Identify this island, a United States commonwealth in the Caribbean.

After having much of his legislation overturned by the Supreme Court, this leader proposed his court packing plan. The Tennessee Valley Authority was one piece of New Deal legislation that was not overturned by the Court. Although he led his country for most of World War II, he did not make the decision to drop the atomic bombs on Japan. He succeeded Herbert Hoover. Who is the only President of the United States to be elected to more than two terms in office?

This artist's statues of a dying slave and a horned Moses were to adorn the tomb of Julius II. His only signed work is one in which Mary holds the dead body of Jesus, entitled Pietà. One of his works depicts a nude giant killer holding a sling. This man depicted several scenes from Genesis in The Last Judgement. Name this Italian Renaissance painter of the Sistine Chapel ceiling.

One theory of this entity's creation states that a Mars-sized body named Theia collided with its parent planet. This object exhibits synchronous rotation with its parent planet, and that rotation results in the namesake "dark side" of this object. The Sea of Tranquility lies on what astronomical body responsible for the Earth's tides, its largest natural satellite?

This left fielder for the Chicago White Sox, known for his exceptional hitting ability and illiterate background, allegedly participated in the infamous Black Sox Scandal of 1919. Despite being acquitted in court, he was banned from baseball for life by Commissioner Kenesaw Mountain Landis. His lifetime batting average of .356 remains the fourth-highest in Major League Baseball history. Who is this player, nicknamed "Shoeless Joe" for once playing a game without his cleats due to blisters?

Located on the Yangtze River Delta in East China, this city is home to the world's busiest container port and is divided into two sections by the Huangpu River. It is a major financial hub and home to the third tallest building in the world. Its unique cityscape features a mix of traditional Chinese architecture and modern skyscrapers. What is the name of this city, known for its historic Bund waterfront and vibrant nightlife?

The sale of this iconic Memphis property was recently stalled by a Tennessee judge. This mansion, located on Elvis Presley Boulevard, was purchased in 1957 for just over $100,000 from a woman named Ruth Moore, whose family had built the home two decades earlier. It's famous for its Jungle Room, a Polynesian-inspired den complete with a 15-foot waterfall. The property includes a Meditation Garden, the final resting place of the King of Rock and Roll and several of his family members. What is this iconic Memphis landmark, a pilgrimage site for Elvis fans worldwide?

This philosopher's method of questioning, known as "elenchus," involved a series of inquiries aimed at exposing contradictions and inconsistencies in a person's beliefs. He never wrote down his ideas, but his student Plato recorded his teachings in dialogues like "The Republic" and "Apology." This philosopher was sentenced to death by hemlock for "corrupting the youth of Athens." Name this ancient Greek thinker, considered the father of Western philosophy.

This British rock band's 1985 Live Aid performance is regarded as one of the greatest live performances in history. The band, known for their flamboyant stage presence and operatic harmonies, was founded in London in 1970 by Freddie Mercury, Brian May, Roger Taylor, and John Deacon. Their 1975 single stayed at the top of the UK charts for nine weeks and is considered one of the greatest rock songs of all time. Who is this iconic band, whose music has sold over 300 million records worldwide?

This 1876 battle, a major turning point in the Great Sioux War, saw Lakota, Northern Cheyenne, and Arapaho warriors led by Sitting Bull and Crazy Horse defeat the U.S. 7th Cavalry Regiment. It took place near a river in Montana Territory, and is often romanticized as "Custer's Last Stand." This victory for Indigenous forces was short-lived, as the U.S. Army eventually prevailed in the war. Name this battle, which has been the subject of numerous films and books.

One variety of this faith is outlined in the Pali Canon. Another variety venerates those who become enlightened but remain in samsara, called bodhisattvas. Those varieties are Theravada and Mahayana.  Adherents to another variety of this faith meditate on koans such as "What is the sound of one hand clapping?". Name this Asian faith that venerates Siddhartha Gautama.

Responsible for the formation of salts like table salt, this chemical bond results from the transfer of electrons between atoms, creating oppositely charged ions that attract each other. It is typically formed between metals and nonmetals, and its strength is determined by the magnitude of the charges and the distance between the ions. What is this type of bond called?

This Canadian city, situated on the northwestern shore of Lake Ontario, is actually built on a glacial plain. It is home to a group of 15 islands which were formed by sediment deposits and erosion. The city's Don River Valley, carved by the last ice age, is a popular natural area for hiking and biking. What is the name of this city, the largest in Canada and the fourth largest in North America?

This British filmmaker began his career designing title cards for silent films. His 1929 film, Blackmail, was the first British "talkie." He was knighted by Queen Elizabeth II in 1980, just a few months before his death. He directed suspenseful thrillers such as "Psycho," "Vertigo," and "North by Northwest," earning him the nickname the "Master of Suspense." Who is this iconic director, known for his cameo appearances in his own films?

Policies during this war included the "strategic hamlet" program and the use of Agent Orange as a defoliant. The Battle of Khe Sanh was fought during this war, which ended with the fall of Saigon, a city that was renamed after the victorious side's leader, Ho Chi Minh. A memorial wall in Washington, DC lists the American casualties of what conflict in Southeast Asia?

This British Prime Minister surprisingly called for a snap election to be held on July 4, 2024. Before becoming Prime Minister, he served as the Chancellor of the Exchequer beginning in 2020 under Boris Johnson. He was born in Southampton and received an MBA from Stanford University as a Fulbright Scholar. Name this man who has led the United Kingdom's Conservative Party since 2022 when he became the first British Asian Prime Minister.

This two-time Olympic gold medalist and two-time FIFA Women's World Cup champion was the youngest woman to ever play for the U.S. national soccer team at the age of 15. She held the record for most international goals scored until 2013 and still ranks third in the history of the U.S. team for international caps and first for career assists. She is married to former MLB shortstop Nomar Garciaparra. Who is this legendary soccer player, often considered one of the greatest female athletes of all time?

This play's opening brawl is started by Gregory and Samson. Later in this play, Friar John fails to deliver a letter written by Friar Lawrence. Mercutio is killed by Tybalt in Act III of this play. This play features the feud between the Montagues and the Capulets. Name this Shakespeare tragedy, depicting a doomed romance between the two title "star-crossed lovers."

This landmark Supreme Court case centered on a Texas state law that criminalized abortion in most instances. The plaintiff, a pregnant woman seeking to terminate her pregnancy, challenged the law's constitutionality. The Court's 1973 decision established that a woman's right to have an abortion was protected by the constitutional right to privacy. Name this controversial case, which was later overturned in 2022 by Dobbs v. Jackson Women's Health Organization.

Built on 43 hills and surrounded by the Pacific Ocean and a bay, this city is home to the infamous former prison on Alcatraz Island and a man-made island initially built for a World's Fair. Locals often refer to the city's frequent fog by the name "Karl". What is this city known for its steep streets, including the crooked Lombard Street?

Nicknamed the "First Lady of Song", this jazz vocalist was known for her scat singing and ability to imitate instruments with her voice. She won her first Grammy in 1958, becoming the first African-American woman to do so. Who is this iconic singer, known for her collaborations with Louis Armstrong and Duke Ellington?

This American transportation service experienced an outage between New York and Philadelphia on May 21 and 22 causing major delays for commuters. The service was founded in 1971 as a quasi-public corporation and is headquartered in Union Station in Washington D.C. Nearly 87,000 passengers ride more than 300 of the service's trains daily. In 2022, they served 22.9 million passengers. Name this rail service with service in 46 U.S. States.

This man fought against Ariovistus, a German leader, and Vercingetorix, a chieftain of the Arverni whose defeat is described in this man's book, Commentaries on the Gallic Wars. He led his troops across the Rubicon to start a civil war with Pompey, one of his partners in the First Triumvirate. Name this Roman leader who was assassinated by Brutus on the Ides of March.

This NBA team's home court, Madison Square Garden, is often referred to as "The World's Most Famous Arena." The team's colors are orange, blue, and white. They have won two NBA championships, both in the early 1970s, with a team that included legends like Walt Frazier and Willis Reed. In 1994, they made it to the NBA Finals but lost to the Houston Rockets. What is the name of this team, located in New York City?

Two liquids are said to be immiscible if they cannot combine to form this type of mixture. In the most common form of this mixture, solid particles are small enough to completely dissolve in a liquid. Name this type of mixture that is not a colloid or suspension, an example of which is sugar dissolved in water.

The most winning woman he ever knew was hanged for poisoning three little children for their insurance-money. Irene Adler, always THE woman to this man, outwitted him during his investigation of 'A Scandal in Bohemia.' This man returned in 'The Adventure of the Empty House' after battling Professor Moriarty to the death. Name this detective faithfully accompanied by John Watson.

This Supreme Court case centered around a Louisiana state law mandating racial segregation on trains. The plaintiff, a man of mixed race, deliberately violated this law to challenge its constitutionality. The Court's controversial ruling in 1896 established the doctrine of "separate but equal," which upheld racial segregation in public facilities for decades. Name this landmark case, which had a profound impact on the civil rights movement in the United States.

In the Spring of 2024, this rapper revitalized a feud with Drake by releasing the first in a series diss tracks, "Euphoria", in response to Drake's release of "Push Ups" and "Taylor Made Freestyle". This Pulitzer Prize-winning rapper released his debut studio album, "Section.80," in 2011, which gained critical acclaim and established him as a rising star in hip hop. His subsequent albums, including "Good Kid, M.A.A.D City," "To Pimp a Butterfly," and "DAMN.," explored themes of race, identity, and social justice, earning him numerous awards and accolades. Name this West Coast rapper who first released music under the name K.Dot in high school.

Discovered in 1799 by French soldiers during Napoleon's Egyptian campaign, this black basalt slab contains a decree issued in Memphis, Egypt, in 196 BCE on behalf of King Ptolemy V Epiphanes. Its inscription is written in three scripts: hieroglyphics, Demotic script, and Ancient Greek. This allowed scholars to decipher hieroglyphics, unlocking the secrets of Ancient Egypt and revolutionizing our understanding of this ancient civilization. What is the name of this artifact, now housed in the British Museum in London?

The Euler line passes through the orthocenter, circumcenter, and centroid in this figure. The area of this polygon can be found by halving the product of two sides and the sine of the angle opposite of the third side or by simply using Heron's formula. It is the only polygon that cannot be concave, because its angles must add to 180 degrees. Name this polygon with three sides.

At one point in this musical, Dr. Dillamond sings "Something Bad." At another point, Madame Morrible announces that the main character is now an enemy of the town, and that character then sings "Defying Gravity." The two heroines in it were originally played by Kristin Chenoweth and Idina Menzel. The relationship between Elphaba and Glinda is documented in what musical based on The Wizard of Oz?

In this novel, a town is fooled by two men who pull off the Royal Nonesuch, and those men go on to steal the property of the late Peter Wilkes. The Widow Douglas wants to "sivilize" the title character, who misses a turn at Cairo and keeps floating south. Name this novel that sees Jim and the title friend of Tom Sawyer travel down the Mississippi River, a work by Mark Twain.

This NBA team's colors are navy blue, gold, and cool gray. They have won three championships, all in the ABA, and have a fierce rivalry with the Detroit Pistons. Reggie Miller, one of their most famous players, is known for his clutch three-pointers and trash-talking. What is the name of this team currently coached by Rick Carlisle, based in Indianapolis, Indiana?

The Andean type of these entities occurs beneath a continental plate, and it is at these sites that about 20% of Earth's crust has been consumed. This antithesis of the mid-oceanic ridge is usually typified by lines of volcanoes running parallel near an oceanic trench. Identify this region where tectonic plates collide, and one goes underneath the other.

This character was named after the wife of King Leontes in The Winter's Tale. This character forms an organization called S.P.E.W., and purchases a half-cat, half-kneazle known as Crookshanks. Though she is called a 'mudblood' because of her dentist parents, she is smart enough to have memorized "Hogwarts: A History." Name this female companion to Harry and Ron in the "Harry Potter" series.

In Spring 2024, Kenya committed 1,000 police officers to help diminish gang violence in this nation as part of a U.N. sanctioned mission which is being financed by the United States. On July 7, 2021 the president of this nation was assassinated and no replacement has been chosen. The country has a recent history of devastating earthquakes leading to increased poverty. Name this Caribbean nation, once a French colony known as Saint-Domingue, is where the Vodou religion originated.

The title character in the movie "V for Vendetta" wears a mask depicting this man. In 1605, this devout Catholic attempted to assassinate King James I of England by blowing up the House of Lords during the State Opening of Parliament. He was discovered in the cellar beneath Parliament and was subsequently tortured and executed. His actions are commemorated annually on November 5th in the United Kingdom, with fireworks displays. Who is this historical figure, whose name has become synonymous with rebellion and conspiracy?

This Union general's "Special Field Order No. 15" promised freed slaves "forty acres and a mule," though it was later revoked. His capture of Atlanta in 1864 boosted Union morale and helped re-elect President Lincoln. He is known for his "March to the Sea," a destructive campaign through Georgia designed to demoralize the Confederacy. Name this general, infamous for his embrace of "total war" tactics during the American Civil War.

While travelling back to his hometown, this man solves a riddle with the answer of 'man.' He kills his own father over the right-of-way at a crossroads. This man fathers his daughter Antigone by his own mother Jocasta, fulfilling a prophecy made at his birth. Name this title character of plays by Sophocles, including one in which he is at Colonus and one in which he is Rex, or The King.

This American tennis player, known for her powerful serve and volley game, won 39 Grand Slam titles throughout her career. She co-founded the Women's Tennis Association and the World TeamTennis league, advocating for gender equality in sports. In 1973, she defeated Bobby Riggs in the highly publicized "Battle of the Sexes" tennis match. Who is this influential athlete, the first prominent female athlete to come out as gay?

A pressure associated with this process is a colligative property proportional to mass and temperature, and is defined as the hydrostatic pressure necessary to counteract this process. A 'reverse' form of this process is sometimes used to purify water. Name this movement of water across a semi-permeable membrane from an area of high concentration to an area of low concentration.

One piece of evidence that supports the existence of this land mass is that the Caledonian mountains of Northern Europe are a continuation of the Appalachian Mountains. This entity broke up into Laurasia and Gondwanaland. Alfred Wegener coined its name during a lecture in which he discussed his theory of continental drift. Name this supercontinent theorized to have existed 250 million years ago.

The size of these objects is given by the Schwarzschild radius. According to quantum mechanics, these objects emit Hawking radiation. One of them, Sagittarius A Star, sits at the center of our galaxy and has four million times the mass of our sun. Name these objects in outer space from which supposedly nothing, not even light, can escape?

This man's wife Jiang Qing was a member of the Gang of Four. He escaped a Kuomintang offensive led by Chiang Kai-shek and went on the Long March in 1934. After he took power in 1949, his government adopted such policies as the Great Leap Forward and the Cultural Revolution. The Little Red Book was written by what Chairman of China's Communist Party?

The oldest person to hold this position was Roger Taney. This office serves as Chancellor of the Smithsonian, and also presides over Presidential impeachment trials. It was held by Charles Evans Hughes, John Marshall, and Earl Warren, the latter of whom wrote an opinion that mandated the so-called 'Miranda Rights'. Name this position currently held by John Roberts Jr., the head of the federal judiciary.
answers: Chief Justice of the Supreme Court
chief justice of the us supreme court
chief justice of the united states supreme court

question: The kicker of this NFL team has recently come under fire for his graduation speech at Benedictine College in Kansas. In the speech, delivered by Harrison Butker, he derided pride month, university diversity initiatives, and suggested that women may not achieve the same fulfillment in careers and they would from homemaking. This team won the Super Bowl in 2023 and 2024 quarterbacked by Patrick Mahomes. Name this NFL team which plays in Kansas City.

This British actor, writer, and director, born in London in 1889, became a global icon for his character "The Tramp," a bumbling yet endearing figure with a bowler hat, cane, and oversized shoes. He was a pioneer in the silent film era, writing, directing, and starring in "The Kid," "The Gold Rush," and "City Lights." He was satirized Adolf Hitler in his 1940 film "The Great Dictator." Who is this legendary figure of early cinema, known for his physical comedy and heartwarming stories?

This NHL team, with their iconic winged wheel logo, has a rich history dating back to 1926, when they were known as the Cougars. They are one of the "Original Six" teams in the NHL and have won 11 Stanley Cup championships, the most of any American team. They are known for their passionate fanbase and the tradition of throwing octopi on the ice during playoff games. What is the name of this team, based in Detroit, Michigan, whose home arena is Little Caesars Arena?

This Australian city, the capital of New South Wales, is home to the world's largest natural harbor, Port Jackson. It's home to Iconic landmarks like the Harbour Bridge, and it is bordered by national parks, including the Royal National Park to the south and the Blue Mountains National Park to the west. The city's most famous landmark, designed by Danish architect Jørn Utzon, has a distinctive sail-like design. What is the name of this bustling metropolis, renowned for its beaches?

Three square windows can be seen in the back of this painting, and the back of a chair takes up its lower center portion. The central figure is wearing red and blue with his hands on a table; to his right is an effeminate figure believed to be the Apostle John. Judas clutches a bag of silver in what Leonardo da Vinci painting that depicts Christ's final meal with his disciples?

During his execution, this figure was pierced by the Lance of Longinus. In addition to yelling at a fig tree for not bearing fruit, this figure healed a pig-eating man from Gerasa possessed by a horde of devils named Legion. This man was put to death by Pontius Pilate, and drops of his blood fell into the Holy Grail. Name this Messiah and only son of God according to Christianity.

This type of chemical bond, formed by the sharing of electron pairs between atoms, is responsible for the stability of many molecules, including water and carbon dioxide. Its strength is determined by the number of shared electron pairs, with double and triple bonds being stronger than single bonds. It is prevalent in organic compounds, forming the backbone of complex molecules like DNA and proteins. What is the name of this bond, which plays a crucial role in the chemistry of life?

In the buildup to this battle, the losing commander set up a fortification at Gloucester shortly after retreating from Williamsburg. A key turning point in this battle was the arrival of reinforcements under Count Rochambeau. British naval forces under Thomas Graves failed to break through the French blockade. Name this final Revolutionary War battle, after which Lord Cornwallis surrendered.

He fulfilled a prophecy by accidentally killing his grandfather Acrisius with a discus. Acrisius had imprisoned his mother, Danae, but Zeus visited her as a golden shower. This man borrowed the invisibility cap of Hades, the reflective shield of Athena, and the winged sandals of Hermes. He slew a sea monster that was about to consume Andromeda, whom he made his wife. Name this figure who beheaded Medusa.

The island of Bornholm is in this body of water, which is connected by the Kiel Canal to the North Sea. One arm of this sea is the Gulf of Bothnia, and the large island of Saaremaa guards its Gulf of Riga. Five national capitals lie on this body of water, including Tallinn, the capital of Estonia, and Stockholm. Name this sea south of Scandinavia.

The International Criminal Court issued an arrest warrant for this international leader in March 2024. This man has served as prime minister of his home nation three separate times making him the nation's longest serving prime minister. Chair of the Likud Party, he was raised in West Jerusalem and the United States. Name this prime minister of Israel who has come under fire from the ICC due to Israel's military operations in Gaza.

This athlete of Native American heritage won gold medals in both the pentathlon and decathlon at the 1912 Stockholm Olympics, only to have them stripped due to a technicality regarding his amateur status.  He later played professional football, baseball, and basketball, becoming the first president of the American Professional Football Association (later the NFL). In 1950, an Associated Press poll named him the greatest athlete of the first half of the 20th century.  Who is this remarkable multi-sport athlete, whose Olympic medals were posthumously restored in 1983?

This Spanish-American chef, known for his innovative tapas, trained under Ferran Adrià at elBulli in Spain. He later moved to the United States, where he opened a series of successful restaurants, including Jaleo, Zaytinya, and minibar. He also founded World Central Kitchen, a non-profit organization providing meals to communities affected by disasters. Who is this culinary icon, named one of Time's 100 Most Influential People in both 2012 and 2018?

The DNA in this organelle is inherited only from the mother. The inner membrane of this organelle contains folds known as cristae and encloses its matrix. This organelle is the site of oxidative phosphorylation, which occurs at the end of the electron transport chain. Name this organelle responsible for cellular respiration, which produces ATP and thus provides energy for the cell.

Born Robert Allen Zimmerman in Duluth, Minnesota, this singer-songwriter's early career was marked by his folk music and protest songs like "Blowin' in the Wind" and "The Times They Are a-Changin'." He later transitioned to electric guitar and rock music, a move that caused controversy among his folk fanbase. His poetic lyrics and distinctive voice earned him a Nobel Prize in Literature in 2016. Name this musician who released his first album in 1962.

This man composed a ballet called The Creatures of Prometheus, and Leonato is a major character in his opera Fidelio. His third symphony was originally written to honor Napoleon and was called Eroica. A later symphony by this man borrows from Schiller's "Ode to Joy" for its choral final movement. Name this composer whose fifth symphony begins with a fate knocking at the door theme and who went deaf before his death in 1827.

This NFL team, established in 1965, has appeared in two Super Bowls, Super Bowl XXXIII and Super Bowl LI, losing both times. The team's iconic "Dirty Bird" dance, popularized by running back Jamal Anderson in the late 1990s, became a symbol of their success during that era.  They currently play their home games at Mercedes-Benz Stadium. What is the name of this team, based in Atlanta, Georgia, whose colors are red, black, silver, and white?

This man won the right to appeal his extradition to the United States for violating the Espionage Act on May 22, 2024. He is currently serving prison time in the United Kingdom for violating the Bail Act due to the fact he dodged a European arrest warrant by taking asylum in the Ecuadorian embassy in London from 2012-2019. Name this Australian founder of WikiLeaks

Born in Nepal during the 6th century BCE, he renounced his royal life at the age of 29 to seek enlightenment and understand the nature of suffering. After meditating under a bodhi tree for 49 days, he attained enlightenment and became known as the "Awakened One." He then dedicated his life to teaching others the path to liberation from suffering, establishing a religion that has profoundly influenced the world for over 2,500 years. Who is this spiritual leader and religious founder?

This landmark Supreme Court case challenged the "separate but equal" doctrine established in Plessy v. Ferguson. The case involved several African American students who were denied admission to public schools attended by white children. The Court's unanimous decision in 1954 declared that racial segregation in public education violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment, effectively overturning Plessy v. Ferguson. Name this case, which marked a major victory for the civil rights movement in the United States.

This European capital city, built on the River Thames, is divided into 32 boroughs. It is home to the Prime Meridian of the World, which passes through the Royal Observatory in Greenwich. The city is also known for its many parks and green spaces, including Hyde Park, Regent's Park, and Greenwich Park. What is the name of this city, famous for its red double-decker buses and black cabs?

J. R. R. Tolkien was inspired to create the Ents by his disappointment with the resolution of a prophecy in this play, in which an army dresses up as trees. Another prophecy in this play is fulfilled when a character reveals that he was born by C-section. A character cries "out, damned spot!" after encouraging her husband to kill Duncan in what Shakespeare play about a Scottish king?

A thinker from this country wrote an essay claiming that "God is dead and we have killed him". A philosopher from this country declared "a specter is haunting Europe" in a work in which he stated, "all history is the history of class struggles". Two philosophers from this country collaborated to write the Communist Manifesto. Name this birthplace of Karl Marx and Friedrich Nietzsche.

This player spent his entire 18-year career with the Pittsburgh Pirates. He was a 15-time All-Star and won 12 consecutive Gold Glove Awards for his exceptional defense in right field. In 1966, he won the National League MVP Award, and in 1971, he was named the World Series MVP. Tragically, he died in a plane crash on December 31, 1972, while delivering aid to earthquake victims in Nicaragua. Name this Hall of Famer who recorded his 3,000th and final career hit in his last at-bat of the 1972 season.

This conflict began with a surprise invasion across the 38th parallel on June 25, 1950. Early successes by the northern forces were reversed by the Inchon Landing, leading to the recapture of the southern capital. Chinese intervention led to a stalemate, and after three years of bloody fighting, an armistice agreement was signed in 1953, leaving this peninsula divided. Name this Cold War conflict.

Gail Halvorsen dropped candy to children in this city during an event that ended a blockade by the Soviets. Checkpoint Charlie was a highly guarded crossing point in this city, where the US helped organize a 1948 airlift. Ronald Reagan demanded that Mikhail Gorbachev "tear down" a structure that divided this city into East and West halves. A Cold War-era wall was located in what capital of Germany?

In May 2024, the ANC Party in this nation did not win a majority in national elections for the first time in 30 years. The current president of this nation is Cyril Ramaphosa who represents the African National Congress Party. The most spoken language in this country is Zulu, and the population is 80% Black but is home to the largest number of white people in Africa. What is this nation where the ANC won the first election after ending apartheid and chose Nelson Mandela as its president in 1994?

Woodie Flowers co-founded a competition involving these things which encourages "gracious professionalism". Czech author Karl Čapek coined the word for these things in his play R. U. R. These things "may not injure a human being" according to the first of three laws for them written by Isaac Asimov. What machines are exemplified by HAL 9000, Bender from Futurama, and droids in Star Wars?

The "dark-field" variety of a technique using these devices involves placing a condenser beneath the diaphragm. These devices may be "finely" or "coarsely" adjusted using two different-sized knobs. Rotating the eyepiece of these devices allows for different levels of magnification. Name these laboratory devices used to observe objects too small to be seen with the naked eye.

Garlic, parsley, and salt may be mixed with this food to create its "compound" type, often used on steaks. To thicken sauces, this food and flour are combined in a roux. The Iowa State Fair commonly houses a cow made of this food. Ghee, commonly used in Indian cooking, is the "clarified" version of this food. Shaking heavy cream in a jar is one way to "churn" what dairy product you might spread on bread?

This scandal involved the secret leasing of federal oil reserves by the Secretary of the Interior to private oil companies in exchange for bribes. It took place during the administration of President Warren G. Harding and led to the conviction of the Secretary of the Interior, making him the first cabinet member to be imprisoned for crimes committed in office. Name this scandal named after a geological formation in Wyoming where one of the oil reserves was located.

A period of low observance of certain features on this body occurred during the Maunder Minimum and they follow an 11-year cycle. The radiative zone causes mass ejections that occur from the hottest layer of this body. The photosphere of this star forms dark areas in regions where certain "spots" form. NASA proposed a HelioSwarm mission to this star using nine probes. Name this closest star to Earth.

The town of Shush in this modern-day country lies near the ancient city of Susa, the capital of the ancient Elamite kingdom. This country's flag contains an emblem of the word "Allah" in calligraphy as well as the words "God is great" written at the borders between its red, white, and green horizontal stripes. The Strait of Hormuz lies south of what country ruled from its capital of Tehran?

This empire, centered in northern Mesopotamia, rose to prominence in the late Bronze Age and became a major regional power during the Iron Age. Known for their advanced military tactics and brutal warfare, they established a vast empire stretching from the Persian Gulf to Egypt. Their capital, Nineveh, was a major center of culture and learning, boasting a vast library of cuneiform tablets. Name this empire that dominated the ancient Near East for centuries, with renowned rulers like Tiglath-Pileser III, Sennacherib, and Ashurbanipal.

This player managed the Cincinnati Reds from 1984 to 1989 while also playing on the team. He is a 17-time All-Star and won three World Series rings with the Cincinnati Reds and Philadelphia Phillies. In 1985, he broke Ty Cobb's all-time hits record, finishing his career with 4,256 hits. Name this player who received a lifetime ban from baseball due to accusations of gambling on games.

This basketball player and announcer died on May 27, 2024. He won two NCAA championships at UCLA and was a three-time National College Player of the Year. He was selected first overall in the 1974 NBA draft and went on to win two NBA championships with the Portland Trail Blazers and Boston Celtics. Known for his unique personality, outspoken views, and colorful commentary, he has become a beloved figure in the basketball world. Name this Hall of Famer known for his Grateful Dead fandom and signature tie-dye attire.

Instruments in this family may be tuned with pegs or fine tuners found near the bridge. Rosin is used to make friction when playing instruments in this family. F-holes are found in instruments in this family, which can be played "pizzicato", or plucked, but are usually played with a bow. Antonio Stradivari made instruments in this family, including basses and cellos. Violins are what kind of instrument?

This conflict began in response to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in August 1990. It involved a massive U.S.-led coalition of 35 nations. The conflict consisted of two main phases: Operation Desert Shield, the buildup of troops and defense of Saudi Arabia, and a similarly named operation, a 42-day air campaign followed by a 100-hour ground offensive that liberated Kuwait. Name this conflict that took place in the Persian Gulf in 1991.

This musician gained fame as a member of the Yardbirds and Cream before embarking on a successful solo career. Known for his blues-inspired guitar playing and soulful vocals, he has released numerous hit albums and singles, including "Layla," "Tears in Heaven," and "Wonderful Tonight." He is the only three-time inductee to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, having been honored for his work with the Yardbirds, Cream, and as a solo artist. Name this guitarist known for his signature song "Cocaine" and his nickname "Slowhand."

In a story by this author, a school is built so a thief can get in, but may not get out. This author's The Sketch Book of Geoffrey Crayon features a short story where the title character falls asleep in the Catskills for 20 years. This author of "Rip Van Winkle" wrote about Brom Bones, who impersonates a dead Hessian soldier to scare Ichabod Crane. Name this author of "The Legend of Sleepy Hollow."

This footballer won the Ballon d'Or in 1998, the same year he led France to victory in the World Cup, scoring two goals in the final against Brazil. In 2001, he transferred to Real Madrid for a then-world record fee. Known for his elegant playing style and exceptional technique, he scored a memorable volley in Real Madrid's 2002 Champions League final victory. Name this midfielder who infamously headbutted Marco Materazzi in the 2006 World Cup final, his last professional match.

This river receives the Green River in Canyonlands National Park before flowing downstream into Lake Powell. Low water levels in Lake Mead, which this river flows through, have raised concern of a "dead pool" when this river will not be able to flow through Hoover Dam. This river forms the border between California and Arizona. The Grand Canyon was carved by what river named for a Rocky Mountain state?

At the end of 2023 this company announced a lawsuit against OpenAI for copyright infringement. In 2022, Sarah Palin lost a case against this company after it linked her to the shooting of Gabby Giffords. This newspaper won a landmark 1964 court case against L. B. Sullivan, and along with the Washington Post, Daniel Ellsberg gave this newspaper the “Pentagon Papers.” Nicknamed “The Old Gray Lady,” Name this newspaper with the motto “All the News That's Fit to Print,” headquartered in Manhattan.

Orbital resonance with Jupiter causes certain points called Kirkwood gaps in one region to be devoid of these objects. Some of these objects that share sections of Jupiter's orbit are called trojans. Vesta and Ceres are the largest of these objects, one of which hit Earth and caused the K-T extinction. What rocky bodies are found most commonly between Mars and Jupiter in a namesake "belt"?

This empire, with its capital at Constantinople, emerged as the eastern continuation of the Roman Empire after the fall of the Western Roman Empire in the 5th century. It lasted for over a thousand years, preserving and transmitting Greco-Roman culture, while also developing its own unique traditions in art, architecture, and law. Name this empire known for its iconic landmark, the Hagia Sophia, and its powerful emperors like Justinian I.

The top quark has the highest value of any particle for this property. Particles with a positive value for this property
interact with the Higgs field. Photons are able to move at the speed of light because they have a
value of zero for this quantity. The gravitational force between two objects is directly
proportional to what quantity measured in kilograms?

This Supreme Court case involved a defendant who was interrogated by police without being informed of his right to remain silent or his right to an attorney. The Court held that suspects in custody must be informed of these rights before questioning, and any statements made without this warning are inadmissible in court. Name this landmark 1966 case that established the requirement for police to issue a formal warning bearing the name of this case.

To farm this crop, the ancient Igorot people terraformed Banaue in the modern-day Philippines to construct massive terraces. The cultivation of millet and this crop around 4,000 years ago was enabled by irrigation next to the Yellow River. Ancient Indians began harvesting this crop's basmati type, which grows during the monsoon. Many Asian cultures used paddies to grow what widely consumed grain?

This man was found guilty on June 11, 2024 on federal charges related to firearm possesion. This man's laptop was a major right-wing story during the 2020 election. He published a memoir titled Beautiful Things. When he was two years old, his mother and his one year old sister died in a car accident. Name this son of President Joe Biden who has struggled with drug abuse especially after the death of his older brother, Beau.

One form of this Hindu god, Kurma, was a turtle who supported Mt. Meru during the Churning of the Ocean. This god is the chief deity of the Vaishnavist tradition. This god is often depicted resting on the serpent Anantashesha, often alongside his consort Lakshmi. The Dashvatara are the ten most famous avatars of this Hindu god. Which Hindu god known as The Preserver has avatars including Rama and Krishna?

This team won its first NBA championship since 1975 by defeating the Cleveland Cavaliers in the 2015 NBA Finals. Led by the "Splash Brothers" duo of Stephen Curry and Klay Thompson, they reached five consecutive NBA Finals from 2015 to 2019, winning three championships. Their head coach, Steve Kerr, was a former NBA player who won five championships as a player with the Chicago Bulls and San Antonio Spurs. Name this team that plays its home games at the Chase Center in San Francisco.

Two artists walked across this structure to each other in a performance called The Lovers, only to break up afterwards. At the start of one movie, Shan Yu leads an attack on this structure. To deter a Hun invasion, Qin Shi Huang ordered the building of this structure. Astronauts have debated whether this man-made structure is visible from space. What defensive structure was built to protect China?

This musician co-founded a band known for their influential music and cultural impact during the 1960s. He was a prolific songwriter, penning classics like "Help!," "Strawberry Fields Forever," and "Imagine." His partnership with Paul McCartney produced some of the most iconic songs in rock history. An outspoken advocate for peace and social justice, he and his wife Yoko Ono became symbols of the counterculture movement. Name this singer and songwriter who was tragically assassinated in 1980, ending his solo career and leaving a lasting legacy as a musical icon.

This person is said to have caused the "Miracle of the Sun" after appearing to three children in Fátima, Portugal. The prayer most commonly recited during the rosary is addressed to this figure, and calls her "full of grace". The doctrine of the Immaculate Conception concerns this figure, whose titles include "Queen of Heaven". Catholics affirm the "perpetual virginity" of what mother of Jesus?

Points of minimal motion on "standing" types of these entities are called nodes. Two of these entities may undergo constructive or destructive interference. Refraction causes these entities to change direction when passing between media. These things are defined by their frequency, amplitude, and namesake "length". Name these oscillations which, in the ocean, will often "break" near the shore.

Alluvial fans are created when these geographic features transition from mountainous to flat
terrain. Oxbows are created when parts of these features are cut off, and many of these features
are surrounded by flat floodplains. Examples of these features that flow into larger ones are
called tributaries. Name these features that carry fresh water into the oceans.

A "revolution" named for this color was pioneered by Nobel Peace Prize winner Norman Borlaug. In the election of 2000, Ralph Nader ran with a party named for this color. To spread a movement named for this color, Gaylord Nelson created Earth Day. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez proposed a "New Deal" of this color supported by Greta Thunberg. Name this color that environmental activists might tell you to "go."

This musician co-founded a band known for its eclectic musical style, blending elements of rock, folk, country, and blues. He was renowned for his improvisational guitar solos and distinctive vocals. His band's concerts were legendary for their extended jams and loyal fan base known as "Deadheads." Name this musician who led the Grateful Dead for over three decades.

This nation recently elected its first female president who will also be its first Jewish president. The current president goes by his initials, AMLO, and created the Moreno Party which is represented by the newly elected Claudia Sheinbaum. This nation is one of the top two trading partners with the United States, and US companies have recently been moving more manufacturing to this country in what has been called "friendshoring" -- shifting production from geopolitical foes to allies. Name this North American nation.

Thirteen people surround one of these objects in a Salvador Dalí painting featuring a translucent human torso and arms. Tintoretto oriented one of these objects diagonally in his version of the same Biblical scene. Jesus, his apostles, and Judas sit behind one of these objects, which is covered in plates and bread, in a painting by Leonardo da Vinci. What pieces of furniture are typically included in depictions of the Last Supper?

This coach led the Los Angeles Lakers to four NBA championships in the 1980s and the Miami Heat to one in 2006. Known for his slicked-back hair and Armani suits, he is credited with developing the "Showtime" era of Lakers basketball, emphasizing fast breaks and high-scoring games. He also coached the New York Knicks to the NBA Finals in 1994. Name this Hall of Famer who currently serves as the president of the Miami Heat.

This Louisiana native was born Stephanie A. Gregory in 1979. She was a key witness in the trial which led to the first criminal conviction of a US President. In the trial the prosecution argued that Michael Cohen paid this person $130,000 to deny she had an affair a decade earlier with Donald Trump. Name this pornstar whose affair with Donald Trump led to his conviction on 34 counts of falsifying business records.

This empire, located in Mesopotamia, rose to prominence under the reign of Hammurabi, who is known for his code of laws, one of the earliest surviving legal texts.
