It reached its peak of power in the 6th century BCE under Nebuchadnezzar II, who is credited with building the Hanging Gardens of Babylon, one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World. Name this empire that conquered the Kingdom of Judah and exiled its people to Babylon.

The "Six Arrows" represent the ideology of this country's founder, who introduced the Latin alphabet to it and banned the wearing of fezzes. This country contains the largest population of Kurds in its southeast, and its first president was Mustafa Kemal Atatürk. In 1922, the Ottoman Empire was replaced by what country which contains the transcontinental city of Istanbul?

This 1999 film follows an insomniac office worker who forms an underground organization with a charismatic soap salesman named Tyler Durden. Their club evolves into an anti-establishment organization called Project Mayhem. The film is known for its twist ending revealing a shocking truth about the relationship between the narrator and Tyler Durden. Name this film directed by David Fincher and starring Edward Norton and Brad Pitt.

This composer incorporated jazz and ragtime elements into pieces like "Ebony Concerto" and "Ragtime for Eleven Instruments." He gained international fame after collaborating with the Ballets Russes on pieces like "The Firebird" and "Petrushka." A premiere of his ballet "The Rite of Spring" sparked a riot due to its dissonant music and unconventional choreography. Name this Russian composer of "Pulcinella" and "The Soldier's Tale."

Disorders of this organelle are typically maternally inherited because this organelle, along with chloroplasts, became part of the cell through endosymbiosis. This organelle's matrix is the site of the Krebs cycle. This organelle produces most of the cell's ATP through cellular respiration so it can be used to produce chemical energy. Name this organelle sometimes called the "powerhouse of the cell."

This coach is known for his implementation of the triangle offense and his incorporation of Zen Buddhism into his coaching philosophy. He led the Chicago Bulls to six NBA championships in the 1990s, coaching Michael Jordan and Scottie Pippen, and the Los Angeles Lakers to five championships in the 2000s, coaching Shaquille O'Neal and Kobe Bryant. Name this 11-time NBA champion coach, the most in league history.

This Supreme Court case involved multiple same-sex couples who challenged state bans on same-sex marriage. The Court held that the Fourteenth Amendment requires states to license and recognize marriages between two people of the same sex. Name this landmark 2015 case that legalized same-sex marriage nationwide.

This poet wrote about a train in the poem "I like to see it lap the Miles". This poet concluded another poem by declaring that "the Horses' Heads / were toward Eternity". This poet wrote "How dreary – to be – Somebody!" in a short poem that exemplified her use of dashes. Name this "Belle of Amherst" who wrote "I'm Nobody! Who are you?" and "Because I could not stop for Death".

Protestors found the large shoe collection of this country's first lady Imelda during the People Power Revolution. The Muslim Moro people resisted this country's colonization by the US after the Spanish-American War. The son of this country's former dictator Ferdinand Marcos succeeded Rodrigo Duterte. This country was named after a Spanish king who colonized it. What country's capital is Manila?

Morgan Spurlock, the creator of this 2004 documentary film died on May 23, 2024. The film follows a filmmaker who embarks on a 30-day experiment, consuming only McDonald's food for every meal. The film documents the detrimental effects of this diet on his physical and psychological health, as well as the broader implications of the fast-food industry's marketing and influence on public health. Name this film which sparked widespread debate about the dangers of fast food and its contribution to the obesity epidemic.

This science fiction film, directed by Stanley Kubrick and co-written with Arthur C. Clarke, follows a voyage to Jupiter after the discovery of a mysterious black monolith. It explores themes of human evolution, artificial intelligence, and extraterrestrial life. The film is known for its groundbreaking special effects, ambiguous ending, and use of classical music, including Richard Strauss's "Also Sprach Zarathustra." Name this 1968 film featuring the iconic sentient computer HAL 9000.

This coach led the Boston Celtics to nine NBA championships and is known for his signature victory cigar. He drafted future Hall of Famers such as Bill Russell and Larry Bird, and is credited with breaking racial barriers by drafting Chuck Cooper, the first African American player in the NBA. Name this legendary coach and executive who is considered one of the most influential figures in NBA history.

This constant is the only positive number for which squaring it is the same as adding 1 to it. The ratio of a regular pentagon's diagonal length to its side length is equal to this constant. The ratio of consecutive terms in the Fibonacci sequence approaches this constant. Name this value equal to about 1.618 which is often associated with natural or artistic beauty.

This country's flag reflects the myth that a city in it was founded where an eagle was seen eating a snake atop a cactus. A civilization from this modern day country worshipped a god that took the form of a "feathered serpent," named Quetzalcoatl. At Tenochtitlan, a civilization from this country performed human sacrifice for its gods.The myths of the Aztec civilization are from what country?

An activist for this non-feminist cause changed their name from Isabella Baumfree after saying "the Spirit calls me, and I must go". In support of this cause, the Secret Six funded a raid on Harpers Ferry led by John Brown. Harriet Beecher Stowe's novel Uncle Tom's Cabin helped drum up support for this cause. Sojourner Truth promoted what cause accomplished by the 13th Amendment and the Emancipation Proclamation?

This 1993 science fiction adventure film, directed by Steven Spielberg, follows a group of scientists and a lawyer who are invited to preview a theme park on a tropical island inhabited by genetically engineered dinosaurs. The park's security systems fail, leading to a chaotic series of events as the dinosaurs escape their enclosures. Name this film featuring iconic creatures like the Tyrannosaurus rex and Velociraptors, based on the novel by Michael Crichton.

This player was selected second overall in the 2007 NBA draft. He won the NBA Rookie of the Year Award and was named the Most Valuable Player in 2014 while playing for the Oklahoma City Thunder. He has won two NBA championships and two Finals MVP awards with the Golden State Warriors. Name this 13-time All-Star known for his scoring ability and signature shoe line with Nike.

Peremptory challenges may be used to remove members of these groups. Members of these groups may be "sequestered" away from media to prevent outside influence. The 6th Amendment granted the right to an "impartial" one of these groups, which must be unanimous to convict. Indictments are delivered by "grand" examples of what groups of 12 people who deliver verdicts in court cases?

This language was used to write a short story collection whose name translates to "Fictions," which includes the stories "Library of Babel" and "The Garden of Forking Paths." The town of Macondo is built by members of the Buendía family in a novel in this language titled One Hundred Years of Solitude. Jorge Luis Borges and Gabriel García Márquez wrote in what language used by most Latin American writers?

This political scandal involved the secret sale of arms to Iran in exchange for the release of American hostages held in Lebanon. The proceeds from the arms sales were then illegally used to fund anti-communist rebels in Nicaragua, known as the Contras. It occurred during the second term of the Reagan administration and involved several high-ranking officials, including Oliver North. Name this scandal that involved covert operations and raised serious questions about the executive branch's authority in foreign policy.

This city's “Orloj”, the world's oldest operating astronomical clock, is mounted to its Old Town Hall. During the “Velvet Revolution”, many demonstrations were held in this city's Wenceslas Square. Statues of various saints line this city's historic Charles Bridge, which spans the Vltava River. Many historic defenestrations occurred in what capital of Czechia?

This dynasty, founded by Liu Bang in 206 BCE, lasted for over four centuries and is considered a golden age in Chinese history. It saw significant advancements in art, technology, and governance, including the establishment of the Silk Road, the invention of paper, and the development of a sophisticated bureaucracy. Name this dynasty that is divided into Western and Eastern periods, with its capital initially at Chang'an and later at Luoyang.

Levels of this molecule decrease during the “austral spring” when its concentration, measured in Dobson units, reaches its lowest values. The Montreal Protocol helped levels of this molecule over Antarctica rise to previous levels by banning CFCs, which caused its namesake atmospheric "hole." UV radiation is absorbed by the stratosphere’s “layer” of what molecule with chemical formula O3?

After a conflict, this city was the target of a rebellion known as the Mercenary War. This Phoenician colony was legendarily founded by the queen Dido. A general from this city encircled a much larger force to achieve a victory at Cannae. Scipio Africanus defeated this city, whose forces marched elephants across the Alps while led by Hannibal. What ancient city in North Africa lost the Punic Wars to Rome?

Ezra Pound wrote "translations" of poems from this country like "The River-Merchant's Wife" despite not knowing its language. A poem from this country describes "bowing my head" and "frost upon the ground". "Drinking Alone by Moonlight" and "Quiet Night Thought" are by a poet from this country. The Monkey King, Sun Wukong, appears in a novel from what country where Li Bai wrote during the Tang Dynasty?

Bruhat Soma won this competition in a lightning-round tiebreaker in May 2024. This annual event began in 1925 with nine contestants and has since grown to include millions of participants from across the United States and several other countries. It is open to students who have not passed the eighth grade and have not reached their 15th birthday. Name this prestigious competition hosted in Washington, D.C. that is known for its challenging words and impressive displays of spelling prowess.

This Disney animated film, initially titled "King of the Jungle," was considered a "B-project" while the studio focused on "Pocahontas." It features a voice cast that includes Matthew Broderick, James Earl Jones, and Jeremy Irons, who temporarily lost his voice while recording "Be Prepared." Its iconic soundtrack, composed by Elton John and Tim Rice, includes songs like "Circle of Life," "Hakuna Matata," and "Can You Feel the Love Tonight," which was almost cut from the film. Name this 1994 highest-grossing hand-drawn animated feature of all time.

This Supreme Court case arose from a dispute over the appointment of a justice of the peace in the District of Columbia. The Court ruled that a provision of the Judiciary Act of 1789, which granted the Court the authority to issue certain writs, was unconstitutional. This decision established the principle of judicial review, the power of the Court to declare acts of Congress unconstitutional. Name this landmark 1803 case that solidified the Supreme Court's role in the system of checks and balances.

A nine-point one of these shapes can be drawn to pass through the midpoints of its given triangle's sides. Right triangles are usually drawn inside one of these shapes in the Cartesian plane to explain the calculation of trig functions. A line between two points on one of these shapes is called a chord. Name these shapes whose circumference is equal to pi times their diameter.

This team relocated to Nashville in 1997 after playing in Houston as the Oilers since 1960. They reached Super Bowl XXXIV in 2000 but lost to the St. Louis Rams by one yard in the final seconds. Their star running back, Derrick Henry, has won two NFL rushing titles and was named the NFL Offensive Player of the Year in 2020. Name this team that plays its home games at Nissan Stadium.

This city, located on the island of Honshu, is the most populous metropolitan area in the world. Situated at the head of a bay sharing its name, it is a major economic and cultural center, home to iconic landmarks such as the Imperial Palace. Name this city, formerly known as Edo, that was devastated by the Great Kantō earthquake in 1923 but has since been rebuilt into a modern metropolis.

This 1991 psychological thriller follows a young FBI trainee who enlists the help of an incarcerated and manipulative cannibalistic serial killer to catch another serial killer, known as "Buffalo Bill," who skins his victims. The film features iconic performances by Jodie Foster as Clarice Starling and Anthony Hopkins as Hannibal Lecter, and won five Academy Awards, including Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor, Best Actress, and Best Adapted Screenplay. Name this film based on the novel by Thomas Harris.

John Cage added screws to make a "prepared" form of this instrument, which is silent for four minutes and 33 seconds in another Cage piece. Scott Joplin's Maple Leaf Rag is played on this instrument. Thelonious Monk and Duke Ellington were famous jazz players of this instrument. "Tickling the ivories" refers to playing what instrument with 88 black and white keys?

This Supreme Court case involved challenges to state laws establishing racial segregation in public schools. The Court held that such segregation violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment, declaring that "separate educational facilities are inherently unequal." Name this landmark 1954 case that overturned the "separate but equal" doctrine established in Plessy v. Ferguson and paved the way for desegregation in the United States.

GUIs in this programming language can be developed using the Swing API. This language developed by Sun Microsystems has the slogan "Write Once, Run Anywhere", advertising its namesake "virtual machine". Much of the original codebase of Minecraft was written in this programming language. Name this popular object-oriented programming language whose symbol is a cup of coffee.

This battle's name was applied to an 1819 massacre against government reform protestors in Manchester. Borders were resolved using terms set at the Congress of Vienna after this battle, at which Prussian forces under von Blucher fought alongside the Duke of Wellington. When this battle's loser was exiled to St. Helena, the French monarchy was restored. What 1815 battle was Napoleon's final defeat?

This fighter defeated Trevor Berbick in 1986 to become the youngest heavyweight champion in history at the age of 20. Known for his ferocious punching power and intimidating presence, he won his first 19 professional fights by knockout. In 1992, he was convicted of rape and served three years in prison. After his release, he regained the heavyweight title but lost it to Evander Holyfield in 1996. In a rematch the following year, he was disqualified for biting Holyfield's ear. Name this boxer nicknamed "Iron Mike."

A bend in this river created an exclave of Fulton County named for the town of New Madrid. The cities of Natchez and Vicksburg are located on the banks of this river. Part of this river's flow drains to the ocean through the Atchafalaya, and this river joins the Ohio River at Cairo, Illinois. St. Louis is located on the west bank of what river which flows through New Orleans into the Gulf of Mexico?

This mans interpreter, Ippei Mizuhara, plead guilty to bank fraud and tax evasion related to illegal gambling debts. This player made his MLB debut with the Los Angeles Angels in 2018, becoming the first player since Babe Ruth to both pitch and hit regularly in the major leagues. He won the American League Rookie of the Year Award in 2018 and was named the American League Most Valuable Player in 2021. In 2023, he became the first player in MLB history to win a home run title and record ten pitching wins in the same season. Name this two-way Japanese superstar known for his exceptional talent as both a pitcher and a designated hitter.

The Ten Days of Repentance are observed immediately following this holiday. Righteous people's names are recorded in the Book of Life on this holiday. During this holiday, people eat apples dipped in honey and may use the greeting "shanah tovah", which means "good year". The first day of Tishrei and the first of the Jewish High Holy Days is what holiday that celebrates the Jewish New Year?

This country is home to the "Catatumbo lightning", an intense localized thunderstorm that occurs for hours a day almost half the days of the year. This country's "tepui", or flat-topped "table mountains", inspired the South American landscape in the Pixar movie Up. The world's highest uninterrupted waterfall, Angel Falls, is located in what South American country led from Caracas?

This region is described by the Three Cell Model, where it is divided into Hadley, Ferrel, and polar cells. The planetary boundary layer is the lowest part of this region of the atmosphere. The
top of this region contains jet streams. This region is where most of Earth's weather occurs. Name this layer of the atmosphere that lies below the stratosphere.

This team relocated to Los Angeles in 2016 after playing in St. Louis since 1995. They won Super Bowl LVI in 2022, defeating the Cincinnati Bengals at their home stadium, SoFi Stadium. Their star defensive tackle, Aaron Donald, is a three-time NFL Defensive Player of the Year and a Super Bowl champion. Sean McVay, their head coach, is the youngest head coach in NFL history to lead a team to the Super Bowl. Name this team that shares SoFi Stadium with the Los Angeles Chargers.

The blood from the right half of this figure was said to bring the dead back to life. Stheno and Euryale were siblings of this child of Ceto, who gave birth to Chrysaor upon her death. A body part of this figure was placed upon the Aegis shield by Athena. This figure was transformed into a monster after Poseidon assaulted her at a temple to Athena, and was slain by Perseus. Identify this gorgon whose gaze petrified men.

Zero Moustafa inherits one of these places in a Wes Anderson film set in Zubrowka. The caretaker of one of these places writes "All work and no play makes Jack a dull boy" hundreds of times in the film The Shining. A group of British pensioners move to India in a film titled for "The Best Exotic Marigold" one of what kind of place where Kevin spends hundreds of dollars on room service in Home Alone 2?

This tennis player lost his first match before the fourth round of the French Open when he lost to Alexander Zverev in the first round in 2024. He won his first French Open title in 2005 at the age of 19, becoming the second-youngest man to win a Grand Slam singles title. He is known for his powerful left-handed forehand, exceptional athleticism, and relentless fighting spirit. He has won a record 14 French Open titles, earning him the nickname "King of Clay." Name this Spanish tennis player who has also won four US Open titles, two Wimbledon titles, and one Australian Open title, for a total of 22 Grand Slam singles titles.

One event in this city occurred on King Street and resulted in Thomas Preston's trial and the death of Crispus Attucks. The Old North Church in this city was the site of the "one if by land, two if by sea" command to Paul Revere. The Sons of Liberty threw goods into this city’s harbor in one event. The Battle of Bunker Hill took place in what city, where tea was destroyed in a namesake 1773 “Tea Party”?

This figure skater became the first American woman and the second woman to land a triple axel in competition. She won the U.S. Figure Skating Championships in 1991 and 1994, but her career was overshadowed by her association with the attack on fellow skater Nancy Kerrigan in 1994. She pleaded guilty to hindering prosecution and was banned for life from the U.S. Figure Skating Association. Name this controversial figure skater portrayed by Margot Robbie in a 2017 film.

Paul Robeson played the title character of this play in its longest-running New York theatre production. The main character of this play is convinced by a handkerchief that his wife is cheating on him. In this play, Emilia is killed for exposing the treachery of her husband Iago. Desdemona is smothered with a pillow in what Shakespeare play about a "Moor of Venice"?

One of this leader's speeches discusses a "frightful despotism" and forbids "entangling
alliances." The Newburgh Conspiracy and the Conway Cabal were plots to replace this leader with
Horatio Gates after this leader's losses at Germantown and Brandywine. After issuing his
farewell address warning against political parties, this leader retired to Mount Vernon. Name this President of the United States.

This neo-noir mystery film follows an aspiring actress named Betty, who befriends an amnesiac woman named Rita after she survives a car crash. As they try to uncover Rita's identity, they become entangled in a web of dreams, illusions, and Hollywood conspiracies. This film is known for its surreal imagery, non-linear narrative, and ambiguous ending, leaving much open to interpretation. Name this 2001 film directed by David Lynch, named after a famous Los Angeles road that is often cited as one of the greatest films of the 21st century.

This city was home to the Francis Scott Key Bridge which collapsed on March 26, 2024 after a cargo ship named Dali collided with the bridge. The city, located on the Patapsco River in Maryland, was a major shipbuilding center during World War II and is home to Fort McHenry, where "The Star-Spangled Banner" was written during the War of 1812. It is also known for its distinct neighborhoods, such as Fells Point and Federal Hill, and its unique culinary traditions, including a famous crab cake. Name this city, nicknamed "Charm City," that is the largest city in Maryland.

Juan Sebastian Elcano continued one of this explorer's expeditions after they were killed by forces under Lapu-Lapu at the Battle of Mactan. This explorer's voyage to the Spice Islands made them the first to discover a strait south of South America, which was later named for them. Name this Portuguese explorer who died while attempting the first circumnavigation of the earth.

An airport in this city is nicknamed "The Busiest Square Mile on Earth". The South Shore Line is a commuter train connecting this city to South Bend. The codes MDW and ORD are used for airports in this city. This city's elevated trains, nicknamed the "El", converge in a downtown area named the Loop. Midway Airport and O'Hare Airport serve what most populous city in Illinois?

Orbital resonance with Jupiter causes certain points called Kirkwood gaps in one region to be devoid of these objects. Some of these objects that share sections of Jupiter's orbit are called trojans. Vesta and Ceres are the largest of these objects, one of which hit Earth and caused the K-T extinction. What rocky bodies are found most commonly between Mars and Jupiter in a namesake "belt"?

Al Smith's adherence to this faith may have caused his election loss to Herbert Hoover. Prejudice against Italian immigrants to America was partially driven by their adherence to this faith, along with Irish-American immigrants such as the Kennedys. In 2020, Joe Biden became the second president in American history to be a member of what "Roman" Christian denomination?

In early June, this news organization's executive editor abruptly resigned after disagreements with the organization's CEO, Will Lewis. This newspaper, founded in 1877, gained national prominence for its investigative reporting during the Watergate scandal in the early 1970s. Reporters Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein played a crucial role in uncovering the Nixon administration's involvement in the break-in at the Democratic National Committee headquarters. Name this newspaper, owned by Jeff Bezos which is headquartered in Washington D.C.

The KGB may have killed a leader of this group, Dag Hammarskjöld, in a plane crash over present-day Zambia. An "educational, scientific, and cultural organization" within this group recognizes world heritage sites. This group's Security Council gives unilateral vetoes to five permanent members, including Russia. What international organization headquartered in New York has 193 member states?

This scientist discovered that the plane of polarization for linearly polarized light can be rotated using an external magnetic field. This scientist's law of induction describes how a magnetic field can produce an electromotive force. This scientist used an ice pail to demonstrate electromagnetic shielding in his namesake cage. Name this English physicist who lends his name to the SI unit of capacitance.

This quarterback, nicknamed "Joe Cool" for his calm demeanor under pressure, led the San Francisco 49ers to four Super Bowl victories in the 1980s. He is renowned for engineering numerous come-from-behind victories, including "The Catch," a last-minute touchdown pass to Dwight Clark in the 1981 NFC Championship Game against the Dallas Cowboys. Name this three-time Super Bowl MVP who is considered one of the greatest quarterbacks in NFL history.

Women in this country may wear a bathrobe-like summer dress known as a yukata. A silk dress from this country is held together by a belt called an obi and may feature designs of Sakura, or cherry blossoms. Ladies-in-waiting like Lady Murasaki during the Heian period were some of the first to wear kimonos in what country, where they're worn by women living in Tokyo?

John Grimes' upbringing in this city is the subject of James Baldwin's novel Go Tell It On the
Mountain. A musician plays piano in this city in the poem "The Weary Blues." An author from this
city asked "What happens to a dream deferred?" in a poem titled for a Black majority
neighborhood in it. Langston Hughes was part of the Harlem Renaissance centered in
what American city?

This artist, born David Robert Jones, adopted his stage name to avoid confusion with Davy Jones of The Monkees. Known for his flamboyant alter egos, including the Thin White Duke, he constantly reinvented his image and sound throughout his career. His music spanned genres like glam rock, art rock, soul, and electronica, with iconic albums like "The Rise and Fall of Ziggy Stardust and the Spiders from Mars," "Heroes," and "Let's Dance." Name this legendary British musician known for his distinctive voice and theatrical performances.

At least 14 Jordanian citizens have died in 2024 during this event due to intense heat. A practice similar to this one, but which can take place at any time of year, is Umrah.
Participants in this practice throw stones at a wall in a ritual "Stoning of the Devil" and reenact
Hajar's search for water by running between two hills. Participants in this event walk seven times
around the Kaaba at the center of the Masjid al-Haram. The Fifth Pillar of Islam is
what pilgrimage to Mecca?

This leader won the Nobel Prize in Literature for A History of the English-Speaking Peoples. This politician was demoted after the Gallipolli campaign during World War I. The "Blood, Sweat, and Tears" speech was given by this man, who succeeded Neville Chamberlain and declared "We shall never surrender" during a war where London was bombed. Name this prime minister who led Britain through World War II.

A faction opposed to this ideology was led by Patrick Henry. This ideology names a series of texts published under the name "Publius" to promote the Constitution, as well as a party that supported the first national bank, a strong central government, and opposed the Democratic-Republicans. Alexander Hamilton wrote most of the "Papers" named for what ideology that names an early American political party?

This element is purified by reducing its oxide in molten cryolite in the Hall-Héroult process.
The Bayer process is used to obtain this element from its ore. It's not chromium, but a
characteristic red color is formed when oxygen and this element form rubies. Bauxite is this
element's most common ore. Identify this thirteenth element often used to make foil,
with atomic symbol Al.

This coach, born in 1913 and known for his houndstooth hat, is considered one of the greatest college football coaches of all time. He led the University of Alabama to six national championships and 13 Southeastern Conference (SEC) titles during his 25-year tenure as head coach. Name this legendary coach whose statue stands outside Bryant-Denny Stadium in Tuscaloosa, Alabama.

This country considered giving the mountain Halti to a neighbor to celebrate that neighbor's 100th birthday. This country's capital was named Christiania until merging with another village in 1925. A museum in this country is dedicated to painter Edvard Munch. This country's west coast, on the Atlantic ocean, is famous for its fjords. Name this Scandinavian country whose capital city is Oslo

This modern-day country was the center of an ancient culture which practiced the black-figure and red-figure styles of painting on pottery. The Elgin Marbles were taken from a building in this country. The sculpture Winged Victory from this country represents the goddess Nike. Praxiteles, a sculptor from this country, created a sculpture of the god Hermes. What country is home to the Parthenon?

This film, featuring memorable scenes of beach volleyball and shirtless pilots, became the highest-grossing film of 1986. Its soundtrack, including Kenny Loggins' "Danger Zone," topped the Billboard charts. The film's iconic motorcycle scene, with Tom Cruise sporting aviator sunglasses and a leather jacket, has been referenced and parodied numerous times in popular culture. Name this film about fighter pilots starring Tom Cruise as Pete "Maverick" Mitchell.

An event involving this activist occurred nine months after a similar one involving 15-year-old
Claudette Colvin. After one action taken by this activist, carpools and taxis were organized to
protest the National City Lines company. A year-long public transit boycott in Montgomery,
Alabama, was sparked by the arrest of what civil rights activist who refused to give up
her bus seat to a white person?

The word "algebra" comes from a word in this language meaning "computation". Maltese is descended from a historic dialect of this language. This is the most-spoken language whose writing system conventionally omits vowels and is written from right to left. The most-spoken Semitic language is what language whose “classical” form is used in the Qur’an and is also spoken in cities like Cairo and Dubai?

This nation's hockey team, comprised of veteran professional players who had dominated international hockey for years, entered the 1980 Winter Olympics in Lake Placid as heavy favorites. They had won the gold medal in four of the previous five Winter Olympic Games and had recently defeated the young and inexperienced U.S. team 10-3 in an exhibition match. In a shocking upset, the U.S. team defeated this team 4-3 in a medal-round game, which became known as the "Miracle on Ice." Against which country did the United States achieve this iconic victory?

In a novel from this country, a "yellow bakkie" is owned by a servant of Maureen and Bamford.
Arthur Jarvis is murdered by Absalom, the son of Stephen Kumalo, in a novel from this country.
The novel July's People was written by this country's author Nadine Gordimer. Alan Paton wrote
Cry, the Beloved Country in what country where many authors wrote about apartheid?

This holiday was celebrated on Monday, June 17, 2024. It is an Islamic holiday, also known as the "Feast of Sacrifice", and it commemorates Ibrahim's (Abraham's) willingness to sacrifice his son as an act of obedience to God. It is celebrated on the 10th day of Dhu al-Hijjah, the twelfth and final month of the Islamic lunar calendar, and typically lasts for four days. Name this important Islamic festival that follows the annual Hajj pilgrimage.

This revolutionary became a symbol of socialist revolution after his execution in Bolivia in 1967. He played a key role in the Cuban Revolution, serving as a guerrilla leader alongside Fidel Castro. He later held positions in the new Cuban government, including Minister of Industries. His iconic portrait, taken by Alberto Korda, has become one of the most reproduced images in the world. Name this Marxist revolutionary born in Argentina.

The Late Heavy Bombardment was a period of intense meteorite impacts on this planet. Banded
iron formations provide evidence for a "great oxygenation event" on this planet. A mass extinction
called the Great Dying occurred at the end of this planet's Permian period. The Cambrian
explosion saw a rapid emergence of life on what 4.5 billion year old planet?

This band, originally named On a Friday, formed in Abingdon, Oxfordshire, England in 1985. They achieved critical acclaim and commercial success with their third album, OK Computer, which is often cited as one of the greatest albums of all time. Their musical style has evolved throughout their career, incorporating elements of alternative rock, electronica, and experimental music. Name this band known for songs like "Creep," "Karma Police," and "Paranoid Android," fronted by Thom Yorke.

This competitor was recently banned from Nathan's Hot Dog Eating Contest on Coney Island due to a sponsorship conflict. Historically, he has dominated the contest, winning a record 16 titles. In 2021, he set a new world record by consuming 76 hot dogs and buns in 10 minutes. He also holds numerous other eating records in various disciplines, including chicken wings, pizza, and Twinkies. Name this competitive eating legend who has become synonymous with the Fourth of July hot dog eating tradition.

This politician served as a Continental Army officer during the American Revolution and later became a successful lawyer in New York. He served as a U.S. Senator from New York and narrowly lost the presidential election of 1800 to Thomas Jefferson, resulting in him becoming Vice President. He killed his political rival, Alexander Hamilton, in a duel in 1804, and was later tried for treason in 1807 for his alleged conspiracy to create an independent nation in the Western territories. Name this controversial figure in early American history.

The story of the Pied Piper originated in this country. In a story from this country, a wife convinces her husband to abandon his children in the forest, and later in that story a girl pushes an old woman into an oven. In another story from this country, the name of a man who spins straw into gold is revealed to be Rumpelstiltskin. Name this country of Brothers Grimm stories such as “Hansel and Gretel.”

This South Korean dark comedy thriller film follows a poor family, the Kims, who scheme their way into working for a wealthy family, the Parks. The film explores themes of social class, inequality, and the parasitic relationships that can develop between those of different socioeconomic statuses. Name this 2019 film directed by Bong Joon-ho, which won four Academy Awards, including Best Picture, Best Director, Best Original Screenplay, and Best International Feature Film, making history as the first non-English language film to win Best Picture.

Early on in this conflict, the defensive "Maginot Line" completely failed to deter an invasion. In
this conflict, the slogan "Work, Family, Fatherland" was adopted by a regime led by former war
hero Philippe Pétain. In this conflict, a French regime based in the city of Vichy was
resisted by the "Free French". Name this conflict during which France was led by a Nazi
puppet government.

One sports team based in this city are nicknamed the "Toffees" and play at Goodison Park. A
team named for this city came back from a 3-0 deficit to win the Champions League in the
"Miracle of Istanbul". The song "You'll Never Walk Alone" is associated with a team in this city,
which plays against Everton in the Merseyside Derby. Name this city whose
namesake club is a longtime rival of Manchester United.

Buddy Holly died in a plane crash near this state's Mason City. This state's highest point is located on a farm near the town of Sibley and is called Hawkeye Point. This state's exclave of Carter Lake lies on the west bank of the Missouri River on its border with Nebraska. Illinois shares the "Quad Cities" with what Midwestern state, the southern neighbor of Minnesota, whose capital is Des Moines?

This anatomical system can be affected by Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, and the Nodes of
Ranvier are found between Schwann cells, a type of glial cell, in this system. Multiple sclerosis
attacks the myelin sheath of cells in this system, and synaptic clefts are crossed by molecules like
acetylcholine and adrenaline to carry impulses throughout it. Neurons are found in
what system which includes the brain?

This neo-noir science fiction film, set in a dystopian Los Angeles in 2019, follows Rick Deckard who is tasked with hunting down and "retiring" four escaped replicants, bioengineered beings indistinguishable from humans. The film is known for its distinctive visuals, philosophical themes about artificial intelligence and what it means to be human, and iconic quotes like "All those moments will be lost in time, like tears in rain." Name this 1982 film directed by Ridley Scott and based on the novel Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep? by Philip K. Dick.

In the largest democratic election in history, this man was reelected to a third consecutive term as prime minister. This man will lead a coaltion government for the first time as his party, the Bharatiya Janata Party, did not win an absolute majority of seats. Although his BJP did not win a majority of seats, their alliance known as the National Democratic Alliance won 293 out of the 543 seats. Name this 14th prime minister of India who was born in 1950.

This player, known for his defensive prowess and intensity, was involved in one of the most infamous incidents in NBA history, the "Malice at the Palace" brawl in 2004. He won the NBA Defensive Player of the Year Award in 2004 and was a key member of the Los Angeles Lakers championship team in 2010. Name this player, who legally changed his name to Metta World Peace in 2011.

This country's Queen Christina abdicated to live with the Pope. In the Thirty
Years' War, this country's king was nicknamed "Lion of the North." A chemist from this country
was nicknamed the "merchant of death" for inventing dynamite. Russia's Peter the Great won the
Great Northern War against this country, which was home to Alfred Nobel. Name
this country led from Stockholm.

The first confirmed discovery of one type of these objects looked at variations in pulsar timing. The Kepler satellite uses transits to look for these objects outside the Solar System. Astronomers are looking for these objects in the "habitable zone" as possible sites of extraterrestrial life. Gas giants are one kind of what objects which orbit stars, such as Venus and the Earth?

This conflict, ended by the Treaty of Ghent, resulted in no significant territorial changes for either side. One of its key battles, the Battle of New Orleans, was a decisive American victory led by Andrew Jackson, yet it occurred after the peace treaty had been signed. Other notable events include the burning of Washington D.C. and the British bombardment of Fort McHenry, which inspired Francis Scott Key to write "The Star-Spangled Banner." Name this war fought between the United States and Great Britain from 1812 to 1815.

A sports team was named for these animals to honor an author who died in that team's city. The narrator of one poem says that one of these animals "will leave me, as my Hopes have flown before". In that poem, this animal is told to "get thee back" to "the Night's Plutonian shore!". This animal sits on a bust of Pallas after "rapping at my chamber door". What bird repeats the word "nevermore"?

The U.S. Army blasted heavy metal to lure this country's leader Manuel Noriega out of hiding in Operation Just Cause. Walter Reed's research on yellow fever aided in the completion of a project that began after this country's independence from Colombia. That project, overseen by Theodore Roosevelt, improved Pacific-Atlantic ship travel. What Central American country's isthmus is home to a namesake canal?

This businessman had a pay package worth over $45 billion in stock options approved by shareholders after a Deleware judge initially struck the package down. He also recently dropped a lawsuit against OpenAI, where he was a cofounder, in which he claimed the company had breached its pledge to remain a nonprofit company. Name this entrepenuer who took Twitter private and acts of the CEO of Tesla and SpaceX.

In 1889, this state was devastated by a flood in Johnstown. Labor leaders staged the Homestead
Strike in this state. The working-class "Yinz" in one of this state's cities were employed by Andrew
Carnegie's company, making it the center of the steel industry. To this day, nobody knows how a
crack formed on the bell in this state's Independence Hall. Name this state home to
Philadelphia.

A stickler for fundamentals and discipline, this coach is often quoted for saying, "Winning isn't everything, it's the only thing." This coach led the Green Bay Packers to five NFL championships in seven years, including the first two Super Bowls. His name now graces the Super Bowl trophy. Name this legendary coach whose name is synonymous with excellence and leadership in the world of sports.

This city, which lost to the forces of Epaminondas at the Battle of Leuctra against Thebes, was home to slaves called helots. Lysander won the Battle of Aegospotami for this city to end a war against the Delian League. This city's King Leonidas led 300 men in a last stand at the battle of Thermopylae. Name this militaristic Greek city-state that won the Peloponnesian War against Athens.

This British comedy-drama series follows a dry-witted and unnamed woman as she navigates life in London while dealing with grief, family dysfunction, and complicated relationships. The show is known for breaking the fourth wall, with the main character frequently addressing the audience directly. Created by and starring Phoebe Waller-Bridge, it is based on her 2013 one-woman show of the same name. Name this critically acclaimed series that won multiple Emmy Awards, including Outstanding Comedy Series and Outstanding Lead Actress in a Comedy Series.

It's not the NGA's sculpture garden, but Louise Bourgeois created a bronze spider for one of these places. Frank Gehry designed one of these buildings in Bilbao, Spain. Frank Lloyd Wright designed a spiral-shaped ramp for another of these museums, which is located on Fifth Avenue in New York City. Name these art museums founded by a philanthropist with the first name Solomon.

Kupffer cells produce bilirubin in this organ from the breakdown of certain cells. This organ is primarily responsible for storing glucose as glycogen in humans. Deoxygenated blood is carried from the spleen to this organ by the portal vein. Bile is produced by this organ and then transported to the gallbladder for storage. Alcohol abuse harms what largest internal organ in humans?

The governance of this country's indigenous Haida people is based on a traditional gift-giving
ceremony called the potlatch. James Evans developed a syllabic alphabet in this country which is
now used for languages such as Cree and Inuktitut, the most-spoken language among its Inuit
people. The "First Nations" are the indigenous people of what country where the
Squamish people lived in British Columbia?

This company briefly surpassed Apple as the most valuable public company in the world. The company, founded in 1993, initially focused on developing graphics processing units (GPUs) for the gaming market. However, it has since expanded its reach to include artificial intelligence, data centers, and autonomous vehicles. Its GPUs are now widely used in various fields, including scientific research, machine learning, and cryptocurrency mining. Name this company, headquartered in Santa Clara, California, known for its GeForce series of GPUs.

In one contest, this figure asks Vafthruthnir about what he whispered in the ear of his son. This deity hung himself from Yggdrasil for nine days in order to learn about runes, and he uses the ravens Huginn and Muninn as messengers. This owner of the horse Sleipnir drank from the Well of Mimir in exchange for his eye. Identify this Norse "All Father," the ruler of the gods, and father of Thor.

This infamous criminal gained notoriety during the Great Depression era for his daring bank robberies and multiple prison escapes. He was declared "Public Enemy No. 1" by the FBI and became a folk hero to some who admired his defiance of authority and his Robin Hood-like image. He was ultimately killed in a shootout with federal agents outside the Biograph Theater in Chicago in 1934. Name this notorious gangster whose exploits captivated the nation and solidified his place in American criminal lore.

This team, one of the original NBA franchises, has a long and storied history, including a remarkable run of eight consecutive championships from 1959 to 1966 under legendary coach Red Auerbach. Led by Hall of Famers such as Bill Russell, Bob Cousy, and John Havlicek, they established themselves as a dominant force in the league. More recently, they reached the NBA Finals in 2022 and ultimately secured their 18th championship in 2024, led by Jayson Tatum and Jaylen Brown. Name this team that holds the record for the most NBA championships.

This object was described as a "small cloud" by Persian astronomer Abd al-Rahman al-Sufi in 964. It takes its name from the constellation in which it appears, which is named for the mythological wife of Perseus. This object is predicted to collide with the Milky Way in about five billion years. Name this member of the Local Group, the closest spiral galaxy to the Milky Way.

Gordon Sumner, known professionally by this stage name, rose to fame as the frontman, bassist, and principal songwriter of the new wave rock band The Police. After the band's breakup in 1986, he embarked on a successful solo career. He is known for his distinctive voice, socially conscious lyrics, and hits like "Every Breath You Take," "Englishman in New York," and "Fields of Gold." Name this English musician who has sold over 100 million records worldwide.

This heir presumptive to the Austro-Hungarian throne was assassinated in Sarajevo in June 1914. His death, at the hands of Gavrilo Princip, a Serbian nationalist, sparked a chain of events that led to the outbreak of World War I. Name this archduke whose assassination is considered a key catalyst for one of the deadliest conflicts in human history.

This island nation, located in the Persian Gulf, is an archipelago consisting of 50 natural islands and an additional 33 artificial islands. It is connected to Saudi Arabia by the King Fahd Causeway, a 25-kilometer bridge, and is separated by a small section of a Persian Gulf from Qatar. This country is the third-smallest nation in Asia by area and is home an international circuit, which hosts an annual Formula One race. Name this country with its capital at Manama.

This country's capital city was designed in the shape of an airplane around a "Monumental Axis" by architect Oscar Niemeyer. "Cariocas" are residents of this country's second most populous city, which was the origin of bossa nova music and hosts massive parades in the Sambodrome during Carnaval. Name this Portuguese-speaking country in South America which contains most of the Amazon rainforest.

This NHL team won their first Stanley Cup in franchise history in 2024, defeating the Edmonton Oilers in seven games after initially being up 3-0 in the series. The team lost to the Vegas Golden Knights in the Stanley Cup Finals in 2023. This team, founded in 1993 as an expansion franchise, experienced a Cinderella run to the Stanley Cup Finals in 1996, ultimately losing to the Colorado Avalanche. Name this NHL team based in Sunrise, Florida.

This law enforcement official served as the first Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), holding the position for 48 years under eight presidents. He is credited with modernizing the FBI and transforming it into a major crime-fighting agency, but his legacy is also controversial due to his use of surveillance and intimidation tactics against political activists and civil rights leaders. Name this influential figure in American law enforcement who remains a subject of debate and scrutiny.

This coming-of-age drama film, directed by Barry Jenkins, tells the story of a young African-American man named Chiron as he grapples with his identity and sexuality while growing up in a rough Miami neighborhood. It garnered critical acclaim for its poignant storytelling, powerful performances, and exploration of themes such as masculinity, family, and self-discovery. Name this film that won the Academy Award for Best Picture in 2017 after a dramatic mix-up during the live announcement, where "La La Land" was initially mistakenly declared the winner.

A woman in this novel is fired from her factory job for having a child out of wedlock. The protagonist of this novel is given silver candlesticks by a bishop. Gavroche catches a police officer at a barricade in this novel, who kills himself after being mercifully freed. Eponine Thenardier saves the life of Marius in this novel. Name this novel about the ex-convict Jean Valjean by Victor Hugo.

This pharaoh, who ascended to the throne at the age of nine, reigned for only about a decade before his untimely death at around 19. His tomb, discovered in 1922 by Howard Carter in the Valley of the Kings, was remarkably intact, containing a wealth of treasures and artifacts that provided valuable insights into ancient Egyptian life and burial practices. Name this "boy king" whose tomb's discovery sparked a worldwide fascination with ancient Egypt.

This prehistoric monument, constructed over multiple phases spanning centuries, features a circular ditch and bank, a ring of bluestones transported from Wales, and a horseshoe arrangement of massive sarsen stones. Its alignment with the sunrise on the summer solstice suggests a connection to solar events and possibly astronomical observations. Name this iconic megalithic structure located on Salisbury Plain in Wiltshire, England, a UNESCO World Heritage Site that continues to be a source of fascination and speculation.

These objects have a clinamen, or a tendency to swerve, as stated by Lucretius in On the Nature of Things. These objects have electron clouds, which are not represented in the Bohr model of them. Democritus believed that these objects made up everything in the universe. The Greek word for "indivisible" provided the name of what fundamental units of matter that can be combined into molecules?

This Netflix historical drama chronicles the life of Queen Elizabeth II, starting with her early years and ascension to the throne. Claire Foy and Olivia Colman have both portrayed the monarch in different stages of her life. The show delves into the personal and political challenges faced by the royal family, including the Suez Crisis, the Aberfan disaster, and Princess Margaret's relationship with Peter Townsend. Notably, the series has received numerous awards, including Golden Globes and Emmys. What is the name of this critically acclaimed show?

This Spanish writer, once captured by Barbary pirates, is best known for a two-part novel published in 1605 and 1615. It follows a delusional nobleman who sets out to revive chivalry, accompanied by his pragmatic squire, Sancho Panza.  The novel's characters and themes, deeply ingrained in Western culture, have inspired countless adaptations. It is considered one of the most important works of literature ever written. Who was this author of Don Quixote?

This American League baseball team plays in the oldest active ballpark in Major League Baseball, known for its iconic Green Monster wall. After selling Babe Ruth to the Yankees in 1920, they endured a long "Curse of the Bambino," finally winning the World Series in 2004. They've won nine titles and boast legendary players like Ted Williams, Carl Yastrzemski, and David Ortiz.  What is the name of this Boston-based team?

This country was the primary battleground of a 17th-century conflict that pitted Roundheads, supporters of Parliament, against Cavaliers, those loyal to the monarchy. Religious and political tensions fueled the conflict, leading to the execution of King Charles I in 1649.  A period of republican rule under Oliver Cromwell followed, but the monarchy was eventually restored in 1660 with Charles II ascending to the throne. Which country was the main setting for this civil war?

This dormant stratovolcano, located in the Caucasus Mountains, has two summits, both volcanic domes. It's the highest peak in Russia and the European continent, with the western summit reaching 5,642 meters above sea level. While sulfurous gases are still emitted on its eastern slopes, it is a popular destination for mountaineering and tourism. Notably, it's the 10th most prominent peak in the world, and its glaciers feed several rivers including the Kuban and Malka. What is this mountain called?

The de Broglie wavelength of a particle equals Planck's constant divided by this quantity. This
quantity and position can't be measured with high accuracy at the same time according to
Heisenberg's uncertainty principle. The conservation of this quantity's angular form, whose rate
of change is torque, explains why gyroscopes work. What quantity is equal to an
object's mass times its velocity?

This state was initially claimed by the Dutch in the 17th century under the name New Netherland, with New Amsterdam as its capital.  It was one of the original Thirteen Colonies and played a crucial role in the American Revolution, hosting numerous significant battles. The state's constitution was adopted in 1777 and heavily influenced the United States Constitution. In the 19th century, it was a major center of immigration and commerce, with Ellis Island serving as a gateway for millions of newcomers to the country. Which state is this?

This nation became the first to retrieve soil samples from the dark side of the moon in June 2024. The nation launched its first satellite, Dong Fang Hong I, in 1970 from the Jiuquan Satellite Launch Center using a Long March-1 rocket. It later successfully sent its first crewed mission, Shenzhou 5, into space in 2003, making it the third country to independently achieve human spaceflight. Name this Asian nation which is led by Xi Jinping.

This Republican politician, known for his "Front Porch Campaign," served as the 25th president of the United States from 1897 until his assassination in 1901. A Civil War veteran and former governor of Ohio, his presidency was marked by the Spanish-American War and the annexation of Hawaii. He was shot by an anarchist named Leon Czolgosz while attending the Pan-American Exposition in Buffalo, New York, and died eight days later. Who was this president?

This West African nation, the most populous on the continent, is known for its diverse landscape, ranging from tropical rainforests in the south to savannas in the north. Its largest city, Lagos, is a major economic and cultural hub, while its capital, Abuja, is a planned city built in the 1980s. It is a significant oil producer, with its petroleum industry playing a crucial role in its economy. It is also home to the Niger River delta, one of the world's largest wetlands. What is the name of this country?

Based on a comic book series of the same name, this post-apocalyptic horror television series premiered in 2010 and ran for 11 seasons. The story follows a group of survivors, led by former sheriff's deputy Rick Grimes, as they navigate a world overrun by zombies, referred to as "walkers." The show explores themes of survival, morality, and the breakdown of society. What is the name of this show that was filmed primarily in Georgia?

The rate at which this process occurs is over 100 times normal rates due to human activity in
the Holocene epoch. The non-avian dinosaurs underwent this process following a meteor
impact 65 million years ago. Species at risk of this process are classified as endangered or critically
endangered. Name this process in which all members of a species die out.

Donald Sutherland, one of the stars of this movie which was based on a novel by Richard Hooker, passed away in June 2024. The 1970 film inspired a TV series with the same name. The series, set during the Korean War, followed the lives of medical personnel stationed at the 4077th Mobile Army Surgical Hospital. It featured characters like the irreverent Hawkeye Pierce, the by-the-book Margaret Houlihan, and the wise-cracking Corporal Klinge Its final episode, "Goodbye, Farewell and Amen," remains the most-watched television finale in U.S. history. What is the name of this critically acclaimed and beloved series?

This country is the setting for one of the most iconic works of art in the world, a woodblock print by Katsushika Hokusai created in the early 19th century. The artwork depicts a massive wave towering over boats with this nation's iconic mountain visible in the background. The artwork is often referred to as "The Great Wave" or "The Great Wave off Kanagawa" and is renowned for its striking composition and use of Prussian blue pigment. Which country is the setting for this iconic artwork?

This Major League Baseball team, originally known as the Brown Stockings, adopted its current name in 1900 after a sportswriter remarked on their "cardinal red" stockings. They play their home games at Busch Stadium, which opened in 2006, and are one of the most successful franchises in baseball history, with 11 World Series championships.  Their mascot, Fredbird, is a beloved figure among fans.  Hall-of-Famers such as Stan Musial, Bob Gibson, and Ozzie Smith have donned this team's uniform.

Fought near a Central Pacific atoll sharing its name, this pivotal World War II naval battle saw the U.S. Navy, aided by codebreakers who deciphered a JN-25b message, decisively defeat the Imperial Japanese Navy. The Americans lost the Yorktown, but sank four Japanese aircraft carriers—Akagi, Kaga, Soryu, and Hiryu—crippling Japan's naval strength. Occurring six months after the attack on Pearl Harbor, this battle is considered a turning point in the Pacific Theater. What is the name of this battle?

This state was initially part of North Carolina and was later known as the Southwest Territory. It was the 16th state admitted to the Union on June 1, 1796, with John Sevier as its first governor. Its nickname, "The Volunteer State," stems from its significant contributions to the War of 1812 and the Mexican-American War. During the Civil War, it was the last state to secede and the first to be readmitted to the Union, with both Union and Confederate sympathizers within its borders. Which state is this?

This French Enlightenment writer, known for his wit and satire, penned plays such as "Zaïre" and "Oedipe," as well as the epic poem "La Henriade." He championed civil liberties, freedom of religion, and separation of church and state, often criticizing the Catholic Church and organized religion. His most famous works include the satirical novella "Candide" and the philosophical dictionary "Dictionnaire philosophique." A vocal advocate for social reform, he spent time imprisoned in the Bastille and exiled in England. Who was this influential figure?

A molecule containing this element can be exfoliated by Scotch tape. This element and
hydrogen are often not labeled on structural diagrams. The atomic mass unit is based on an
isotope of this element. Graphene and graphite are allotropes of this element. Organic chemistry
is centered around the properties of this element, which all life is based on. Name this
sixth element with a symbol matching its first letter.

This river is immortalized in Richard Wagner's opera cycle, "Der Ring des Nibelungen," as the dwelling place of water spirits who guard a treasure of gold. Flowing from the Swiss Alps, this river passes through major European cities like Basel, Strasbourg, Cologne, and Rotterdam before emptying into the North Sea. Its scenic middle section is known for its numerous castles. Historically, it has served as a vital trade route and a natural border between nations, playing a significant role in European conflicts. What is the name of this river?

Formed in Los Angeles in 1971, this band's members originally included Glenn Frey, Don Henley, Bernie Leadon, and Randy Meisner. Their debut album, released in 1972, featured hits like "Take It Easy" and "Witchy Woman."  Known for their harmonies and blend of rock, country, and folk influences, they achieved immense commercial success throughout the 1970s with albums like "Desperado," "One of These Nights," and "Hotel California." The band broke up in 1980 but reunited in 1994 for the "Hell Freezes Over" tour and album. What is the name of this iconic American band?

This Indian-born British author, known for his magical realism and historical fiction, faced controversy and a fatwa for his 1988 novel "The Satanic Verses." His works often explore themes of migration, identity, and the clash of cultures.  He won the Booker Prize in 1981 for "Midnight's Children," a sprawling epic about India's transition from British colonialism to independence.  Other notable works include "Shame," "The Moor's Last Sigh," and "Shalimar the Clown." Who is this acclaimed yet controversial author who was attacked on stage in 2022?

This baseball player, sometimes considered the greatest all-around player of all time passed away in June 2024. Nicknamed the "Say Hey Kid," this baseball legend was a 24-time All-Star, 12-time Gold Glove Award winner, and two-time National League MVP. Known for his iconic over-the-shoulder catch in the 1954 World Series, he spent the majority of his career with the New York/San Francisco Giants before finishing with the New York Mets. Name this member of the 3,000 hit club with 660 career home runs which rank him among the all-time leaders.

Nicknamed "Mr. Hockey," this right winger played 26 seasons with the Detroit Red Wings, winning four Stanley Cups. He is known for the a special hat trick—a goal, an assist, and a fight—in a single game.  He was the first player to reach 800 goals and holds the record for most NHL games played with 1,767. His sons Mark and Marty also played professional hockey, even teaming up with him in the WHA. Who is this legendary hockey player?

This baseball team, which plays its home games at T-Mobile Park, joined the American League as an expansion team in 1977. Their name reflects the city's strong maritime heritage, and their mascot, the Mariner Moose, is a beloved figure among fans. They have never won a World Series, but they hold the MLB record for most wins in a single season, achieving 116 wins in 2001. What is the name of this team, whose iconic logo features a compass rose and a stylized "S"?

This Italian Renaissance master, born in 1483, was a child prodigy. He apprenticed to the renowned painter Pietro Perugino at a young age. He was commissioned by Pope Julius II to paint the papal apartments in the Vatican, including his masterpiece, The School of Athens. Despite his untimely death at the age of 37, he left behind a vast body of work, including Madonnas, portraits, and frescoes. Name this artist, considered one of the three great masters of the High Renaissance, alongside Leonardo da Vinci and Michelangelo.

This historic document was sealed at Runnymede in 1215, following a rebellion of English barons against King John; it limited the power of the monarchy, guaranteeing certain rights and liberties to all free men; it established the principle of habeas corpus, preventing unlawful detention; it served as an inspiration for future legal documents such as the United States Constitution. Name this charter, which was written in Latin and means "Great Charter."

Born in rural Mississippi in 1954, this influential figure overcame a challenging childhood to become a media mogul, actress, and philanthropist. She hosted a wildly popular daytime talk show for 25 seasons, which became known for its focus on self-improvement and empowerment. She also founded a successful magazine, launched a cable network, and even acted in films like "The Color Purple" and "Beloved." Name this influential figure who is sometimes referred to as the first Black woman billionaire.

These mammals, belonging to the order Lagomorpha, are known for their distinctive long ears, short fluffy tails, and powerful hind legs. Unlike rodents, they possess two pairs of upper incisors, with a smaller pair located directly behind the larger front teeth. Their diet consists primarily of grasses and leafy greens, and they have a unique digestive system that includes hindgut fermentation. Due to their high reproductive rate, they are often used in scientific research, particularly in studies related to reproduction, genetics, and immunology. What are these animals called?

This actress, whose trademark large eyes and distinctive voice made her a Hollywood icon, was born Ruth Elizabeth Davis in Lowell, Massachusetts, in 1908. She rose to fame in the 1930s and 1940s, known for her fierce independence and willingness to play unsympathetic characters. She had a legendary feud with fellow actress Joan Crawford, which culminated in their collaboration on the 1962 film "What Ever Happened to Baby Jane?".  Name this two-time Academy Award winner, whose career spanned six decades and included memorable roles in films like "Jezebel," "Dark Victory," and "All About Eve."

This country, whose name is derived from the Greek word "Aigyptos," is home to the oldest and only remaining Seven Wonders of the Ancient World. Its capital, the largest city in Africa, is a major cultural and economic hub. It shares a border with Libya to the west and Sudan to the south. Name this nation on the Nile River, whose ancient civilization flourished for over 3,000 years.

This nation led by President William Ruto had mass protests in June 2024 relating to a finance bill which proposed a large increase in taxes. The bill was passed on June 20. Protesters stormed the Parliament building on June 25 which led to the military being deployed to support the police. President Ruto then reversed course stating he would not sign the bill. Name this African nation home to more than 50 million people with a capital of Nairobi.

This river, whose name means "Lion River" in Sanskrit, is one of the longest in Asia, flowing over 3,000 kilometers from its source in the Tibetan Plateau to its delta in the Arabian Sea; it's home to a blind freshwater dolphin species found only in this river system; its basin was the cradle of the one of the world's earliest urban civilizations; it's a major source of irrigation and hydroelectric power for Pakistan and India. Name this river, which holds cultural and economic significance for millions of people.

This barrier was nicknamed the “anti-fascist protection rampart” by Soviet officials. Constructed in 1961, it stood as a physical and ideological division between East and West Germany during the Cold War; its initial purpose was to prevent East Germans from defecting to the West; it became a symbol of communist repression and the Iron Curtain; its fall in 1989 marked a pivotal moment in the collapse of the Soviet Union and the end of the Cold War. Name this infamous barrier, whose graffiti-covered remnants are now a popular tourist attraction.

This fresco painting, located on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel in Vatican City, depicts a scene from the biblical Book of Genesis; it’s one of nine panels illustrating the creation story and is considered one of the most replicated religious paintings of all time; it portrays God reaching out to Adam, their fingers nearly touching, in a moment that symbolizes the divine spark of life; it was painted by Michelangelo between 1508 and 1512. Name this famous artwork, whose composition and symbolism have been widely studied and interpreted.

This TV show, created by David Lynch and Mark Frost, gained a cult following for its surreal atmosphere and unconventional storytelling; its central mystery revolves around the murder of homecoming queen Laura Palmer in the fictional town in Washington; its haunting theme song, composed by Angelo Badalamenti, became instantly recognizable; the show's dream sequences and supernatural elements added to its unique allure. Name this series, revived in 2017 after a 26-year hiatus.

This element, first discovered during a solar eclipse in 1868, gets its name from the Greek word for sun. It's the second most abundant element in the universe, after hydrogen, yet it's relatively rare on Earth; it's lighter than air, which is why it's used to fill balloons and blimps; at extremely low temperatures, it becomes a superfluid, meaning it can flow without any friction. What is this noble gas, known for its ability to alter the pitch of human voices when inhaled?

This athlete, nicknamed “Hammerin’ Hank,” faced racial prejudice and death threats throughout his career, especially as he approached Babe Ruth’s home run record; he began his professional baseball career in the Negro leagues before joining the Milwaukee Braves; in 1974, he broke Babe Ruth’s record of 714 career home runs, finishing his career with 755; he was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1982. Name this baseball legend who played the majority of his career with the Atlanta Braves.

This man's podcast, where he hosts long form interviews, is commonly believed to be the most popular in the United States. His podcast has been both praised for its diverse conversations and criticized for spreading misinformation. He began his career as a standup comedian in the 1980s and gained recognition as a co-host on the reality show "Fear Factor." Name this man who has worked as a commentator for UFC and is known to hold black belts in Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu and Taekwondo.

This influential politician was born in 1947 and graduated from Wellesley College in 1969, where she gave a commencement speech that received national attention. She served as First Lady of the United States from 1993 to 2001 and played a key role in the administration's health care reform efforts. In 2000, she was elected as the first female senator from New York, serving until 2009 when she was appointed Secretary of State. In 2016, she became the first woman to be nominated for president by a major U.S. political party. Name this politician who ran against Donald Trump in the 2016 presidential election.

This novel, first published in Lippincott's Monthly Magazine in 1890, sparked controversy for its themes of hedonism and immorality. Its title character, a young man of extraordinary beauty, wishes that his portrait would age instead of him, a wish that is mysteriously granted. As Dorian indulges in a life of pleasure and sin, his portrait reflects the corruption of his soul, while he himself remains untouched by time. Name this only novel by Oscar Wilde, a cautionary tale about the dangers of vanity and the pursuit of pleasure.

This battle, fought in 480 BC, saw a small force of Greek warriors, including the legendary 300 Spartans led by King Leonidas, hold off a massive Persian army under Xerxes I for three days; it took place at a narrow pass called "Hot Gates" in Greek; despite their valiant defense and the use of phalanx formations, the Greeks were ultimately betrayed and outflanked, leading to their defeat; this battle has become a symbol of courage, sacrifice, and the defense of freedom against overwhelming odds. Name this battle, which was famously depicted in the 2006 film "300."

This Virginia-born politician served as governor of the Indiana Territory from 1801 to 1812, during which he fought against Tecumseh’s Confederacy in the Battle of Tippecanoe; his victory earned him the nickname “Old Tippecanoe” and helped him win the presidency in 1840 with the slogan “Tippecanoe and Tyler Too”; his inauguration speech was the longest on record, lasting nearly two hours in freezing temperatures; he died from pneumonia just 31 days into his term, making his the shortest presidency in US history. Name this president whose death led to the first transfer of presidential power to a vice president.

This actor, born in Dorking, England, trained at the prestigious Central School of Speech and Drama; he gained recognition for his Shakespearean roles on stage, notably his performances as Hamlet, Richard III, and Othello; he was married three times, including a tumultuous relationship with actress Vivien Leigh. Name this influential figure in 20th-century theater and cinema, who directed and starred in several film adaptations of Shakespeare's plays, winning an Academy Award for Best Actor and Best Picture for his 1948 film "Hamlet."

This international organization appointed Mark Rutte, a prime minister from the Netherlands as its next leader. Established in 1949 with the signing of its namesake treaty, this intergovernmental military alliance is headquartered in Brussels, Belgium. Its original purpose was to provide collective security against the Soviet Union during the Cold War. It currently has 32 member states from North America and Europe. Its core principle is collective defense, meaning an attack against one member is considered an attack against all. Name this organization whose actions include the intervention in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the ongoing support for Ukraine.

This animal’s stomach is actually comprised of four compartments: the rumen, reticulum, omasum, and abomasum; they’re known for their ability to digest cellulose, a complex carbohydrate found in plants, thanks to a symbiotic relationship with microbes in their rumen; their digestive process involves regurgitating and rechewing their food, a process called “chewing the cud”; their milk is a major source of nutrition for humans worldwide, providing protein, calcium, and other essential nutrients. Name this common farm animal, known for its gentle nature and black-and-white markings.

This NBA team, founded in 1989, shares its name with their state animal, the grey wolf; their logo features a howling wolf silhouetted against a blue and green background, representing the state's forests and lakes; they play their home games at the Target Center in Minneapolis, Minnesota; despite reaching the Western Conference Finals in 2004, they have yet to win an NBA championship. Name this team, whose current roster includes Karl-Anthony Towns and Anthony Edwards.

This historic city, named after the Greek goddess of wisdom and warfare, is built around a rocky outcrop called the Acropolis, which houses the iconic Parthenon temple. It hosted the first modern Olympic Games in 1896 and is home to the Panathenaic Stadium, the only stadium in the world built entirely of marble. It's considered the birthplace of democracy, with its ancient political system serving as a model for many modern governments. Name this bustling metropolis, the capital of Greece.

This future president was born into a wealthy New York family and endured a sickly childhood with asthma; during the Spanish-American War, he led a volunteer cavalry regiment known as the Rough Riders; he briefly served as New York City’s police commissioner and is famous for his trust-busting policies against monopolies. Name this conservationist who was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for negotiating an end to the Russo-Japanese War.

This pivotal battle, fought in 1066, saw the Norman forces of William the Conqueror defeat the English army under King Harold Godwinson; it took place near the present-day town of Battle, East Sussex, England, and lasted a full day; the Normans' victory marked the end of Anglo-Saxon rule in England and the beginning of the Norman Conquest; it's depicted in the famous Bayeux Tapestry, a 70-meter-long embroidered cloth that tells the story of the battle in intricate detail. Name this battle, which changed the course of English history.

This is the only bone in the human body that’s wider in the middle than at the ends; the strongest part of this bone is the shaft, which can withstand forces of up to 1,800 to 2,500 pounds in a healthy adult. This bone’s name comes from the Latin meaning thigh. Name this longest and strongest bone in the human body, essential for walking, running, and jumping.

This landform, part of the Southern Alps, is composed of three summits: Low Peak, Middle Peak, and High Peak; it holds great cultural significance to the indigenous Māori people, who consider it the most sacred peak; its name, in the Māori language, translates to "Cloud Piercer"; it was renamed in 1851 after a British explorer, although the dual name is now officially recognized. Name this landform, the highest mountain in New Zealand.

This left-handed athlete, born in Prague, Czechoslovakia, defected to the United States in 1975 at the age of 18; known for her aggressive serve-and-volley style, she won 18 Grand Slam singles titles, including a record nine Wimbledon championships; she was a dominant force in doubles, partnering with Pam Shriver to win 20 Grand Slam titles; she held the world No. 1 ranking in singles for a total of 332 weeks, a record at the time. Name this tennis legend who won a total of 59 Grand Slam titles in singles, doubles, and mixed doubles.

Luis Arce, the president of this nation withstood an attempted coup d'état on June 26, 2024. Army commander General Juan José Zúñiga sent troops to seize Plaza Murillo, the central plaza in La Paz, and storm the Casa Grande del Pueblo, the presidential palace. This nation shares Lake Titicaca, South America's largest lake by volume, with its neighbor Peru. It's known for the Uyuni Salt Flats, the world's largest salt flat, and being a significant producer of tin and lithium. Name this country, formerly known as Upper Peru during Spanish colonial rule.

This author’s real name was Eric Arthur Blair, and he was born in Motihari, British India, in 1903. He served in the Indian Imperial Police in Burma before returning to England to pursue a writing career. He adopted his pen name from a river in Suffolk, England. His most famous works, two dystopian novels published in 1945 and 1949, are still widely read and analyzed for their social and political commentary. Name this author, whose works include "Animal Farm" and "Nineteen Eighty-Four."
